On May 5, 2016, Mossack Fonseca sent a cease and desist letter to the ICIJ in an attempt to stop the ICIJ from releasing the leaked documents from the Panama Papers scandal.<ref>{{cite web |language=Spanish |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/piden-publicar-panama-papers/23938374 |title=Piden no publicar Panama Papers |date=May 6, 2016 |website=El Siglo |publisher=El Siglo |access-date=April 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602061930/http://elsiglo.com/panama/piden-publicar-panama-papers/23938374 |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Despite this, the ICIJ released the leaked documents on May 9, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |language=Spanish |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/icij-revelara-panama-papers/23938995 |title=ICIJ revelará hoy 'Panamá papers' |date=May 9, 2016 |website=El Siglo |publisher=El Siglo |access-date=April 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510105803/http://elsiglo.com/panama/icij-revelara-panama-papers/23938995 |archivedate=May 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |language=English |url=https://panamapapers.icij.org/blog/20160509-offshore-database-release.html |title=ICIJ releases database revealing thousands of secret offshore companies · ICIJ |date=May 9, 2016 |website=icij.org |publisher=The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists |access-date=April 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509180916/https://panamapapers.icij.org/blog/20160509-offshore-database-release.html |archivedate=May 9, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In March 2018, Mossack Fonseca announced it would close down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/14/mossack-fonseca-shut-down-panama-papers|title=Mossack Fonseca law firm to shut down after Panama Papers tax scandal|last=|first=|date=|work=The Guardian|access-date=|publication-date=2018-03-14}}</ref>
==Responses in Panama== At 5:00 am on April 3, as the news first broke, [[Ramón Fonseca Mora]] told television channel [[TVN (Panama)|TVN]] he "was not responsible nor he had been accused in any tribunal".<ref name="tvn-2.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Fonseca-Mora-Red-Delitos-Financieros-PanamaPapers_0_4452304801.html |title=Exclusiva: 'No soy responsable ni he sido acusado en un tribunal', Fonseca Mora |website=TVN |access-date=2016-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506225050/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Fonseca-Mora-Red-Delitos-Financieros-PanamaPapers_0_4452304801.html |archivedate=May 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
He said the firm was the victim of a hack and that he had no responsibility for what clients did with the offshore companies that they purchased from Mossack Fonseca, which were legal under Panamanian law.<ref name="tvn-2.com"/> Later that day, the Independent Movement (MOVIN)<ref group=note>MOVIN: an independent political movement based in Panama, focused on influencing and monitoring the independence, efficiency and transparency of government institutions and their management. See {{cite news|title=Civil Society {{!}} Policy Areas {{!}} ERCAS – European Research Centre for Anti-Corruption and State-Building|url=http://www.againstcorruption.eu/policy_areas/civil-society/?post_type=|work=www.againstcorruption.eu|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110145206/http://www.againstcorruption.eu/policy_areas/civil-society/?post_type=|archivedate=November 10, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> called for calm, and expressed hope that the Panamanian justice system would not allow the culprits to go with impunity.<ref name="tvn-2.com"/>
===Public officials=== By April 8, the government understood media reports were addressing tax evasion not attacking the country of Panama.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} The president met on Wednesday April 7, with CANDIF, a committee of representatives from different sectors of the economy which includes the Chamber of Commerce, Chamber of Industry and Agriculture, the National Lawyers Association, the International Lawyers Association, the Banking Association and the Stock Exchange, and entered full [[crisis management]] mode.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bna.com/panama-launches-crisis-n57982069699/ |title=Panama Launches Crisis Talks in Wake of Tax Haven Leaks |website=www.bna.com |access-date=2016-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508162514/http://www.bna.com/panama-launches-crisis-n57982069699/ |archivedate=May 8, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He announced the creation of a new judiciary tribunal and a high-level commission led by Nobel Prize Laureate [[Joseph Stiglitz]].{{when|date=November 2017}}
[[Isabel Saint Malo]] de Alvarado, Vice President of Panama, said in an op-ed piece published April 21 in ''The Guardian'' that President [[Juan Carlos Varela]] and his administration have strengthened Panama's controls over [[money-laundering]] in the twenty months they have been in power, and that "Panama is setting up an independent commission, co-chaired by the Nobel laureate [[Joseph Stiglitz]], to evaluate our financial system, determine best practices, and recommend measures to strengthen global financial and legal transparency. We expect its findings within the next six months, and will share the results with the international community."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/21/panama-papers-tax-haven-financial-transparency |title=Don't blame Panama for the Panama Papers |author=Isabel Saint Malo de Alvarado |date=April 21, 2016 |accessdate=April 23, 2006 |work=The Guardian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422065303/http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/21/panama-papers-tax-haven-financial-transparency |archivedate=April 22, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
However, in early August 2016, Stiglitz resigned from the committee because he learned that the Panamanian government would not commit to making their final report public. He said that he had always "assumed" that the final report would be transparent.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Business/International/panama-papers-commission-credibility-chair-joseph-stiglitz/story?id=41203846 "Panama Papers Commission ‘Will Have No Credibility,’ Former Chair Joseph Stiglitz Says"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811154619/http://abcnews.go.com/Business/International/panama-papers-commission-credibility-chair-joseph-stiglitz/story?id=41203846 |date=August 11, 2016 }}, ''ABC News'', August 9, 2016</ref>
On April 8, President Varela denounced France's proposal to return Panama to a list of countries that did not cooperate with information exchange.<ref>{{cite news |title=Panama threatens France over 'papers' blacklist |url=http://en.rfi.fr/france/20160413-panama-threatens-france-over-papers-blacklist |accessdate=April 26, 2016 |work=RFI |date=April 13, 2016 |language=English |location=France |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423153524/http://en.rfi.fr/france/20160413-panama-threatens-france-over-papers-blacklist |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Minister of the Presidency Alvaro Alemán categorically denied that Panama is a tax haven, and said the country would not be a scapegoat.<ref name=franca>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Panama-Papers-Francia-ParaisoFiscal-OCDE_0_4453804624.html |title=Panamá se defiende y califica de 'irrespetuosas' declaraciones de la OCDE |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224026/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Panama-Papers-Francia-ParaisoFiscal-OCDE_0_4453804624.html |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Alemán said that talks with the French ambassador to Panama had begun.<ref name=franca />
On April 25, a meeting of the Panamanian and French finance ministers resulted in an agreement under which Panama will provide information to France about French nationals with taxable assets in the country.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-france-idUSKCN0XM21L |title=Panama's finance minister faces French counterpart in Paris over tax spat |date=2016-04-25 |newspaper=Reuters |access-date=2016-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426183038/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-france-idUSKCN0XM21L |archivedate=April 26, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/politica/panama-francia-pactan-contra-evasion/23936355 |title=Panamá y Francia pactan contra evasión |date=2016-04-26 |website=La Estrella de Panamá |access-date=2016-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427105804/http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/politica/panama-francia-pactan-contra-evasion/23936355 |archivedate=April 27, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><!-- can't understand this bad translation, and who is this anyway?: Saul Mendez, leader of Suntracs said this scandal are involved high officials of the government, but these will not be achieved for justice. "It is necessary that the flag of the original to sweep the rot that is increasingly felt in government structures constituent to rise" he said.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/renuncias-exterior-panama-pasa-nada/23934262 |title=Renuncias en el exterior y en Panamá no pasa nada |date=April 16, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016}}</ref> -->
The Ministry of Economy and Finance of Panama, Dulcidio de la Guardia, formerly an offshore specialist at Mossack Fonseca competitor Morgan & Morgan, said the legal but often "murky" niche of establishing offshore accounts, firms and trusts make up "less than half a percentage point" of Panama's [[GDP]]. He appeared to suggest that publication of the papers was an attack on Panama because of the high level of economic growth that the country had shown.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6066b3d8-fce1-11e5-a31a-7930bacb3f5f.html |title=Panamanians pained by corruption claims |last=Webber |first=Jude |date=2016-04-07 |newspaper=Financial Times |issn=0307-1766 |access-date=2016-04-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160411020422/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6066b3d8-fce1-11e5-a31a-7930bacb3f5f.html |archivedate=April 11, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Eduardo Morgan of the Panamanian firm Morgan & Morgan accused the OECD of starting the scandal to avoid competition from Panama with the interests of other countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Eduardo-Morgan-detras-OCDE_0_4453804580.html |title=Eduardo Morgan: "detrás de todo esto está la OCDE" |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224237/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Eduardo-Morgan-detras-OCDE_0_4453804580.html |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Panama Papers affect the image of Panama in an unfair manner and have come to light not as the result of an investigation, but of a hack, said Adolfo Linares, president of the Chamber of Commerce, Industries and Agriculture of Panama (Cciap).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Panama-Papers-difamacion-escandalo_0_4453804578.html |title='Panama Papers', una campaña de difamación al país: Adolfo Linares |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224246/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Panama-Papers-difamacion-escandalo_0_4453804578.html |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The Colegio Nacional de Abogados de Panama (CNA) urged the government to sue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nextvpanama.com/noticias/gremio-de-abogados-insta-gobierno-panameno-demandar-por-dano-de-imagen-33991 |title=Gremio de abogados insta a Gobierno panameño demandar por daño de imagen |date=April 6, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224026/http://www.nextvpanama.com/noticias/gremio-de-abogados-insta-gobierno-panameno-demandar-por-dano-de-imagen-33991 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Political analyst Mario Rognoni said that the world perceives Panama as a tax haven. The government of President [[Juan Carlos Varela]] might become implicated if he tries to cover up for those involved, Rognoni said.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/panama-sale-afectado/23932073 |title=Panamá sale afectado |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224622/http://elsiglo.com/panama/panama-sale-afectado/23932073 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Economist Rolando Gordon said the affair hurts Panama, which has just emerged from the greylist of the [[Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering|FATF]], and added that each country, especially Panama, must conduct investigations and determine whether illegal or improper acts were committed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/repercucion-economica/23932074 |title=Repercución económica |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224643/http://elsiglo.com/panama/repercucion-economica/23932074 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Panama's Lawyers Movement called the Panama Papers leak "cyber bullying" and in a press conference condemned it as an attack on the 'Panama' brand. Fraguela Alfonso, its president, said called it a direct attack on the country's financial system.
<blockquote>I invite all organized forces of the country to create a great crusade for the rescue of the country's image</blockquote><!-- unable to understand this: The law firm Rubio, Álvarez, Solís & Abrego also reacted and in a press release said that "In recent decades Panama has been in the most important financial and service centers of Latin America and the entire world. As a result, all kinds of attacks on our service system have been attempted."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/repudian-ataque-imagen-pais/23932263 |title=Repudian ataque a imagen del país |date=April 6, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016}}</ref> -->
Offshore companies are legal, said Panamanian lawyer and former controller of the republic Alvin Weeden; illegality arises when they are used for money laundering, arms smuggling, terrorism, or tax evasion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/sociedades-offshore/23932072 |title=Sociedades offshore |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224715/http://elsiglo.com/panama/sociedades-offshore/23932072 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 19, 2016, it became known that a government executive had just spent 370 million dollars in order to "clean" the country's image.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/ejecutivo-utiliza-370-para-limpiar-imagen/23966616 |title=Ejecutivo utiliza $370 mil para 'limpiar' imagen |date=October 19, 2016 |accessdate=October 19, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020105502/http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/ejecutivo-utiliza-370-para-limpiar-imagen/23966616 |archivedate=October 20, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 22, 2016, in the midst of a state visit to Germany, Varela told journalist Jenny Pérez, of [[Deutsche Welle]] that there had been "progress" in transparency and many agreements to exchange tax information, and that [[tax evasion]] was a global problem. Asked about his ties with Ramón Fonseca Mora, managing partner of the firm Mossack Fonseca, he acknowledged that he is a friend.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Varela-reacciona-cuestionado-Papeles-Panama-entrevista-Jenny-Perez-Alemania_0_4603789596.html |title=La entrevista sobre "Panama Papers" que puso contra las cuerdas al presidente Varela |date=October 22, 2016 |accessdate=October 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161023184105/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/Varela-reacciona-cuestionado-Papeles-Panama-entrevista-Jenny-Perez-Alemania_0_4603789596.html |archivedate=October 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Law enforcement=== The Procuraduría de la Nación announced that it would investigate Mossack Fonseca and the Panama papers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/investigara-mossack-fonseca/23931813 |title=MP investigará a Mossack Fonseca& – El Siglo |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405164458/http://elsiglo.com/panama/investigara-mossack-fonseca/23931813 |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> see On April 12, the newly formed Second Specialized Prosecutor against Organized Crime raided Mossack Fonseca and searched their Bella Vista office as part of the investigation initiated by the Panama Papers. The Attorney General's office issued a press release following the raid, which lasted 27 hours,<ref name=Telraid>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/23/investigators-raid-property-of-panama-papers-law-firm-mossack-fo/ |title=Investigators raid property of 'Panama Papers' law firm Mossack Fonseca |author=Reuters |date=April 23, 2016 |accessdate=April 23, 2016 |publisher=''The Telegraph'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423184402/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/23/investigators-raid-property-of-panama-papers-law-firm-mossack-fo/ |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> stating that the purpose was "to obtain documents relevant to the information published in news articles that establishes the possible use of the law firm in illegal activities".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/judicial/Registran-Mossack-Fonseca-Panama-Papers-panama-papers-efecto-panama-corrupcion-paraisos-fiscales_0_4459054130.html |title=Fiscalía panameña realizó allanamiento en Mossack Fonseca |date=April 12, 2016 |accessdate=April 13, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414193125/http://www.tvn-2.com/nacionales/judicial/Registran-Mossack-Fonseca-Panama-Papers-panama-papers-efecto-panama-corrupcion-paraisos-fiscales_0_4459054130.html |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The search ended without measures against the law firm, confirmed prosecutor Javier Caraballo of the Second Prosecutor Against Organized Crime.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/evita-referirse-futuro-mossack-fonseca/23933897 |title=MP evita referirse al futuro de Mossack Fonseca |date=April 14, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415111605/http://elsiglo.com/panama/evita-referirse-futuro-mossack-fonseca/23933897 |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On April 22 the same unit raided another Panama location and "secured a large amount of evidence".<ref name=Telraid />
The Municipality of Regulation and Supervision of Financial Subjects [not the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF)] initiated a special review of the law firm Mossack Fonseca to determine whether it had followed tax law. Carlamara Sanchez, in charge of this proceeding, said at a press conference that the quartermaster had come to verify whether the firm had complied since April 8 with [[due diligence]], customer knowledge, the final beneficiary and reporting of suspicious transactions to Financial Analysis Unit (UAF) operations. She said that Law 23 of 2015 empowers regulation and supervision and said some firms had been monitored since late last year with special attention after the Panama Papers, and noted that the law carries fines $5,000 to $1 million or even suspension of the firm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/realiza-auditoria-firma-mossack-fonseca/23934086 |title=MEF realiza auditoría a firma Mossack Fonseca |date=April 15, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417003806/http://elsiglo.com/panama/realiza-auditoria-firma-mossack-fonseca/23934086 |archivedate=April 17, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The ICIJ investigation of Mossack Fonseca was reported to the Public Ministry. Samid Dan Sandoval, former candidate for mayor of Santiago de Veraguas (2014), filed the legal action against the journalists and all those who had participated. He said the project name damaged the integrity, dignity and sovereignty of the country. and that the consortium would have to assume legal responsibility for all damage caused to the Panamanian nation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://elsiglo.com/panama/icij-puede-investigado/23933682 |title=ICIJ no puede ser investigado |date=April 13, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414104744/http://elsiglo.com/panama/icij-puede-investigado/23933682 |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
A Change.org petition requested the ICIJ stop using the name of Panama as in the Panama Papers. The request said the generally- accepted name for the investigation "damage(d) the image" of Panama.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/Elevan-peticion-internet-Panama-Papers_0_904710164.html |title=Elevan petición en internet para que se cambie el nombre de Panama Papers |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513150047/http://www.telemetro.com/nacionales/Elevan-peticion-internet-Panama-Papers_0_904710164.html |archivedate=May 13, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Suspension of investigation === Attorney General of Panama Kenia Isolda Porcell Diaz announced on January 24, 2017 that he was suspending the investigations against Mossack Fonseca because it filed an appeal for protection of constitutional rights before the First Superior Court of Justice of Panama and requested that he deliver all the original documents to issue a judgment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gestion.pe/politica/panama-suspendera-investigacion-sobre-panama-papers-2180461 |title=Panamá suspenderá investigación sobre Panama Papers |first= |last=gestion.pe |date=January 24, 2017 |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202041325/http://gestion.pe/politica/panama-suspendera-investigacion-sobre-panama-papers-2180461 |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.laprensalibre.cr/Noticias/detalle/101002/panama-suspendera-investigacion-sobre-panama-papers |title=Panamá suspenderá investigación sobre Panama Papers – laprensalibre.cr |first= |last=www.laprensalibre.cr |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202024609/https://www.laprensalibre.cr/Noticias/detalle/101002/panama-suspendera-investigacion-sobre-panama-papers |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://cdn8.larepublica.pe/mundo/america/842510-panama-papers-procuradora-general-anuncio-suspension-de-investigacion |title=Panamá Papers: procuradora general anunció suspensión de investigación |date=January 24, 2017 |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202025907/http://cdn8.larepublica.pe/mundo/america/842510-panama-papers-procuradora-general-anuncio-suspension-de-investigacion |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>{{clarify|date=October 2017}}
===Charges=== Mossack and Fonseca were detained February 8, 2017 on money-laundering charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN15Q0TK|agency=Reuters|author=Elida Moreno|date=February 11, 2017|accessdate=November 12, 2017|title=Panama detains Mossack Fonseca founders on corruption charges}}</ref>
===Demise of Mossack Fonseca=== In March 2018, [[Mossack Fonseca]] announced that it would cease operations at the end of March due to "irreversible damage" to their image as a direct result of the Panama Papers. <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/14/mossack-fonseca-shut-down-panama-papers</ref>
== Allegations, reactions, and investigations == {{Main|Reactions to the Panama Papers}}
=== Europe ===
==== European Union ==== Many senior EU figures have been implicated in the Panama Papers scandal.<ref name="Politico EU figures">{{cite news |last1=Quentin |first1=Ariès |last2=Paravinci |first2=Giulia |title=5 ways the Panama Papers swept up EU figures |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/5-ways-panama-papers-swept-eu-figures-miguel-arias-canete-david-cameron/ |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |work=POLITICO |date=April 7, 2016 |language=English |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224018/http://www.politico.eu/article/5-ways-panama-papers-swept-eu-figures-miguel-arias-canete-david-cameron/ |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[European Commissioner for Taxation and Customs Union, Audit and Anti-Fraud|European Commissioner for Taxation]], [[Pierre Moscovici]], has said that the [[European Union]] as a whole had a "duty" to prevent the kind of tax avoidance uncovered in the Panama Papers scandal. Moscovici told reporters the use of offshore companies to hide what he called "shocking amounts" of financial assets from tax authorities was "unethical". He estimated that the tax shelters resulted in an annual loss of some €1 trillion in public finances, adding that the [[European Commission]] has attempted to tighten tax rules across the union since November 2014 due to the [[Luxembourg Leaks]] scandal, also revealed by the ICIJ, and that he hoped the extent of the Panama Papers revelations would spur countries to action.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ariès |first1=Quentin |title=EU vows to act quickly on Panama Papers |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/pierre-moscovici-european-union-must-act-quickly-on-panama-papers/ |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |work=POLITICO |date=April 6, 2016 |language=English |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224450/http://www.politico.eu/article/pierre-moscovici-european-union-must-act-quickly-on-panama-papers/ |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In a 2013 letter, unearthed by the ''[[Financial Times]]'' to the then president of the [[European Council]], [[Herman Van Rompuy]], the then [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[David Cameron]] said that offshore trusts should not automatically be subject to the same transparency requirements as shell companies.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stewart |first1=Heather |title=Cameron stepped in to shield offshore trusts from EU tax crackdown in 2013 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/07/david-cameron-offshore-trusts-eu-tax-crackdown-2013 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |work=The Guardian |date=April 6, 2016 |language=English |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407033153/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/07/david-cameron-offshore-trusts-eu-tax-crackdown-2013 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Panama Papers: Cameron's 2013 concern over trust reforms |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-35983222 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |work=BBC News |date=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407000423/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-35983222 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Andorra ==== The Panama Papers revealed that the Minister of Finance of Andorra, [[Jordi Cinca]], while he was CEO of Orfund SA, maintained an offshore company called Mariette Holdings Inc, until its dissolution in 2002 for fear of discovery of his participation in these businesses. The business activities of Orfund had ties to the [[blood diamond]] trade, and the refining and sale of African gold. This company closed shortly before the [[civil war in Ivory Coast]].
The opposition demanded his resignation as a result. In response Cinca said that "if their connection would affect the Government of Andorra, will step down". Still, he did not.<ref>[http://www.andorradifusio.ad/Noticies/cinca-explica-que-va-ser-apoderat-duna-societat-panamenya-entre-el-1999-i-el-2000-arran-dels-papers-de-panama "Andorra Difusió]". ==== Austria ==== Austria's financial market authority has announced that they will audit two Austrian banks that were mentioned in the Panama Papers – [[Raiffeisen Zentralbank|Raiffeisenbank International]] (RBI) and {{Interlanguage link multi|Hypo Vorarlberg|de|3=Vorarlberger Landes- und Hypothekenbank}}. It will be specifically examining whether the banks have complied with their obligation to prevent money laundering. Hypo Vorarlberg subsequently announced that while they have complied with all laws in the past, they are planning to retreat completely from the offshore sector.<ref>{{cite web |title=Riesiges Datenleck enthüllt Offshore-Deals |url=http://derstandard.at/2000034112839/Panama-Papers-Riesiges-Datenleck-enthuellt-Offshore-Geschaefte-von-Putins-Vertrauten |accessdate=4 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405071953/http://derstandard.at/2000034112839/Panama-Papers-Riesiges-Datenleck-enthuellt-Offshore-Geschaefte-von-Putins-Vertrauten |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Cyprus ==== [[Central Bank of Cyprus]] officially declared: "With regard to press reports citing leaked documents, known as the Panama Papers, the Central Bank of Cyprus announces that it is assessing the information to the extent that it may concern the Cypriot banking system and taking, where necessary, appropriate action."<ref name=CM>Angelos Anastasiou (April 4, 2016)[http://cyprus-mail.com/2016/04/04/cyprus-implicated-in-panama-papers Cyprus implicated in Panama papers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024925/http://cyprus-mail.com/2016/04/04/cyprus-implicated-in-panama-papers/ |date=April 6, 2016 }}, Cyprus Mail, retrieved April 5, 2016.</ref> A Cypriot online paper said "The Cyprus link stems from the fact that Fonseca runs an office in Cyprus and, more specifically, in [[Limassol]]. In a chart, the leaks name Cyprus as a tax haven (countries that offer little or no tax), although it has a corporate tax rate of 12.5%, the same as Ireland."<ref name=CM/>
==== Denmark ==== In September 2016, Danish tax authorities purchased Panama Papers data on 320 companies and some 500-600 individuals to investigate. Although the data came from an anonymous source, it was vetted with credible sample data.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dw.com/en/tax-authorities-in-denmark-buy-panama-papers-evidence/a-35928320|title=Tax authorities in Denmark buy 'Panama Papers' evidence {{!}} DW {{!}} 29.09.2016|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thelocal.dk/20160929/denmark-pays-for-panama-papers-data-on-own-citizens|title=Denmark pays for Panama Papers data on own citizens|date=2016-09-29|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.icij.org/blog/2017/12/500-million-recovered-tax-authorities-worldwide-following-panama-papers/|title=More than $500 million recovered by tax authorities worldwide following the Panama Papers - ICIJ|date=2017-12-27|work=ICIJ|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
==== France ==== [[File:Marine Le Pen (2017-03-24) 01 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Marine Le Pen]] ]] French financial prosecutors opened a probe, and former President [[François Hollande]] declared that tax evaders would be brought to trial and punished.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-france-investigation-idUSKCN0X11QQ France opens probe after Panama leaks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019045008/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-france-investigation-idUSKCN0X11QQ |date=October 19, 2017 }}, Reuters (April 4, 2016).</ref> Also as a result of the leak, France restored Panama to its list of tax havens, from which Panama had recently been removed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/francia-vuelve-poner-panama-lista-paraisos-fiscales/23932090 |title=Francia vuelve a poner a Panamá en su lista de refugios fiscales |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |language=es |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024708/http://laestrella.com.pa/panama/nacional/francia-vuelve-poner-panama-lista-paraisos-fiscales/23932090 |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Former French budget minister [[Jérôme Cahuzac]], who spearheaded a crackdown on tax fraud while in office, was a client of Mossack Fonseca and through them owned a Seychelles company named Cerman Group Limited, incorporated in 2009. When France investigated 2013 allegations by [[Mediapart]] that in 2000 Cahuzac had held undeclared assets in an account first in Switzerland, then Singapore, he resigned his cabinet post, protesting his innocence,<ref name=libe>{{cite news |url=http://www.liberation.fr/france/2013/03/19/information-judiciaire-ouverte-dans-l-affaire-cahuzac_889698 |title=Jérôme Cahuzac démissionne |author=Agence France-Presse |date=19 March 2013 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160730033819/http://www.liberation.fr/france/2013/03/19/information-judiciaire-ouverte-dans-l-affaire-cahuzac_889698 |archivedate=July 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> but admitted a few months later that he indeed had hidden €600,000 in a [[UBS]] account and then moved it to keep it hidden, "while continuing to lead France's clampdown on tax evasion".<ref name=lie>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/02/jerome-cahuzac-france-offshore-account |title=France's former budget minister admits lying about secret offshore account |date=2 April 2013 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |author=Angelique Chrisafis |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414125019/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/02/jerome-cahuzac-france-offshore-account |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The French Socialist Party unanimously voted to expel him a week later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2013/04/09/le-bureau-national-du-ps-exclut-jerome-cahuzac-a-l-unanimite_3156859_823448.html |title=Le bureau national du PS exclut Jérôme Cahuzac à l'unanimité |publisher=Le Monde |date=9 April 2003 |accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> On the heels of the April 2013 "Cahuzac affair", President Hollande created the ''parquet national financier'' (PNF), a judiciary investigation unit specializing in large-scale fraud and corruption investigations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/police-justice/article/2015/04/20/premier-bilan-mitige-pour-le-parquet-financier_4619155_1653578.html |title=Premier bilan mitigé pour le parquet financier |author=Simon Piel |date=20 April 2015 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |publisher=Le Monde}}</ref>
[[Jean-Marie Le Pen]], founder and long-time leader of the far-right-wing [[Front National]] (FN) and now a [[member of the European Parliament]], already was the subject, along with his daughter [[Marine Le Pen]] and his staff, of a PNF tax fraud investigation. Drawing official scrutiny were an undeclared [[HSBC]] account containing €2.2m in gold and coins, managed from Geneva by an aide through a trust based in the British Virgin Islands which was closed and then moved to the Bahamas in 2014; allegations of overbilling;<ref name=express>{{cite news |url=http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/politique/fn/l-affaire-riwal-le-bygmalion-version-fn_1646550.html |title=L'affaire Riwal, le Bygmalion version FN |publisher=L'Expresse |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417072123/http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/politique/fn/l-affaire-riwal-le-bygmalion-version-fn_1646550.html |archivedate=April 17, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> misuse and comingling of campaign funds;<ref name=express /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKBN0UL1Y720160107 |title=Enquête du parquet financier sur le patrimoine de Marine Le Pen |date=7 January 2016 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |publisher=Reuters France |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427104856/http://fr.reuters.com/article/topNews/idFRKBN0UL1Y720160107 |archivedate=April 27, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and tax evasion. Jean-Marie Le Pen is also suspected of using his European Parliament funds for the campaign and administrative expenses of his French political party.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2015/03/10/25001-20150310ARTFIG00170-quand-les-partis-remunerent-leurs-cadres-avec-l-argent-de-bruxelles.php |title=Quand les partis rémunèrent leurs cadres avec l'argent de Bruxelles |author=Marc de Boni |publisher=Le Figaro |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=18 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160319013421/http://www.lefigaro.fr/politique/le-scan/2015/03/10/25001-20150310ARTFIG00170-quand-les-partis-remunerent-leurs-cadres-avec-l-argent-de-bruxelles.php |archivedate=March 19, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Jean-Marie Le Pen is mentioned in the documents, along with his daughter Marine Le Pen, who is the current party leader, and [[Frederic Chatillon]], an FN insider who is also a close friend of Marine. Among the three of them, they may have hidden as much as a million pounds in offshore accounts.<ref name=campri>{{cite news |last1=Rayner |first1=Gordon |last2=Morgan |first2=Tom |first3=Ben |last3=Riley-Smith |first4=Kate |last4=McCann |title=Panama Papers: offshore firm set up by Cameron's father was moved to Ireland in year son became PM |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/05/panama-papers-david-cameron-forced-to-declare-tax-affairs-amid-o/ |publisher=The Telegraph |date=April 6, 2016 |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405200445/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/05/panama-papers-david-cameron-forced-to-declare-tax-affairs-amid-o/ |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Georgia ==== [[File:Bidzina Ivanishvili Senate of Poland (cropped).JPG|thumb|upright|[[Bidzina Ivanishvili]], former Prime Minister of Georgia]] [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]] became wealthy in Russia before returning to [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] and becoming prime minister in 2012; his public official's asset declaration was 72 pages long.<ref name=OccIv>{{cite news |url=https://www.occrp.org/en/panamapapers/georgia-ivanishvili-offshore/ |title=OFFSHORE COMPANY SPENT 3 YEARS CHASING IVANISHVILI'S PASSPORT |author1=Nino Bakradze |author2=Dave Bloss |work=OCCRP |date=April 3, 2016 |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531050055/https://www.occrp.org/en/panamapapers/georgia-ivanishvili-offshore/ |archivedate=May 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> However, he does not list Lynden Management, a Mossack Fonseca company which held about 20% of the shares of Raptor Pharmaceuticals (which he did declare), a US-based company listed on the New York Stock Exchange.<ref name=OccIv /> He refused for nearly four years to provide a copy of his passport and a proof of address to the law firm, which needed it to comply with money-laundering regulations as well as inquiries into the company by the Financial Investigation Agency of the British Virgin Islands.<ref name=OccIv />
Forbes calculates Ivanishvili's net worth at $4.8 billion.<ref name=OccIv />
==== Greece ==== The Panama Papers confirmed that the politician [[Stavros Papastavrou]], who was advisor of former Prime Ministers [[Kostas Karamanlis]] and [[Antonis Samaras]], had been a member of the council of the Panamanian foundations, Green Shamrock Foundation and Diman Foundation, from 2005 to 2014. In 2006, he became deputy chairman of the Aisios Foundation, that still exists today. However, Papstavrou resigned from the Aisios Foundation in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://projects.icij.org/panama-papers/power-players/index.html#16 |title=Panama Papers – The Power Players |publisher=ICIJ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160404015649/https://projects.icij.org/panama-papers/power-players/index.html#16 |archivedate=April 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
A number of Greek families with significant art collections were implicated in this scandal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Εταιρείες-φαντάσματα πωλούσαν μέσω Παναμά έργα τέχνης της οικογένειας Γουλανδρή|url=http://www.topontiki.gr/article/166671/etaireies-fantasmata-poloysan-meso-panama-erga-tehnis-tis-oikogeneias-goylandri|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420150128/http://www.topontiki.gr/article/166671/etaireies-fantasmata-poloysan-meso-panama-erga-tehnis-tis-oikogeneias-goylandri|archivedate=April 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==== Iceland ==== {{Main|Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson|Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson|Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1970)|Jón Ásgeir Jóhannesson|Dorrit Moussaieff|Júlíus Vífill Ingvarsson}} [[File:Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugssonin Oct, 2014.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson]], [[Prime Minister of Iceland]], stepped aside on April 5, 2016.]]
Prime Minister [[Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson]], elected after the 2008 banking collapse in Iceland, had pledged to clean up corruption in the banking system. But when Sigmundur Davíð took his seat he did not disclose his 50% interest of Wintris, a company that owned bonds of one of the bankrupt banks, nor divest himself of it, until the day before a new law took effect on January 1, 2010 that would have required him to declare this conflict of interest. He sold his share to his wife, who owns the other half.<ref> {{cite news |title=Iceland's PM says he will not resign in Panama Papers scandal |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/icelands-pm-says-he-will-not-resign-in-panama-papers-scandal-34597940.html |accessdate=April 4, 2016 |work=Belfast Telegraph |date=April 4, 2016 |quote=He allegedly sold his half of the company to Palsdottir for one US dollar on 31 December 31, 2009, the day before a new Icelandic law took effect that would have required him to declare the ownership of Wintris as a conflict of interest.}}</ref> The couple both come from wealthy families. When they bought Wintris he was working as a journalist and she is an anthropologist. Until his failure to disclose the asset, he apparently broke no laws. But the country remembers the 2008 financial crisis all too well and thought it had put it in the past.<ref name=sdstorm>{{cite web |url=http://panamapapers.sueddeutsche.de/articles/56fec0cda1bb8d3c3495adfc/ |title=A storm is coming |author1=Frederik Obermaier |author2=Bastian Obermayer |work=Panama Papers |publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160614065017/http://panamapapers.sueddeutsche.de/articles/56fec0cda1bb8d3c3495adfc/ |archivedate=June 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Since Sigmundur Davíð negotiated on behalf of Iceland with creditors of failed Icelandic banks, the discovery that Sigmundur Davíð's wife is a bondholder caused so much outrage that 22,000–24,000 people attended an [[2016 Icelandic anti-government protests|anti-government protest]] outside the parliament on April 4, 2016, almost 8% of the population.<ref name="McKernan Iceland Protest 2016">{{cite web |last=McKernan |first=Bethan |title=People in Iceland are throwing yoghurt at parliament over the Panama Papers |website=indy100 |date=April 5, 2016 |url=http://indy100.independent.co.uk/article/people-in-iceland-are-throwing-yoghurt-at-parliament-over-the-panama-papers--Z1xciOu_clW |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024902/http://indy100.independent.co.uk/article/people-in-iceland-are-throwing-yoghurt-at-parliament-over-the-panama-papers--Z1xciOu_clW |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Sigmundur Davíð suggested a [[snap election]],<ref name="Guardian: Iceland snap" /> but the other members of the coalition government did not want elections, just his resignation. On April 5, 2016, [[Prime Minister of Iceland]] [[Sigmundur Davíð Gunnlaugsson]] announced his resignation.<ref name="Iceland PM gone">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/05/europe/panama-papers-iceland-pm/index.html |title=Panama Papers fallout: Iceland's prime minister resigns |work=CNN |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405121706/http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/05/europe/panama-papers-iceland-pm/index.html |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/05/europe/panama-papers-iceland-pm/index.html |title=Iceland swears in new PM amid Panama Papers fallout |author3=Holly Yan |author1=Tim Hume |author2=Zoe Robert |date=April 7, 2016 |work=CNN |accessdate=May 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601134912/http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/05/europe/panama-papers-iceland-pm/index.html |archivedate=June 1, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
''[[The Reykjavik Grapevine]]'' and the news site [[Kjarninn]] revealed that President [[Ólafur Ragnar Grímsson]] had connections to Lasca Finance Limited, registered in 2005 in the British Virgin Islands. Ólafur Ragnar had categorically denied any personal or family ties to companies in tax havens. The parents of his wife, [[Dorrit Moussaieff]], operated the company 1999–2005. The financial statements of the Moussaieff [[Shlomo Moussaieff (businessman)|family business]] show it received nearly £7 million ($10.2 million US, €9.1 million) in interest payments from Lasca during 2000–2005. In 2005 Moussaieff Jewelers Limited sold its 10% stake of Lasca to S. Dorrit Moussaieff's deceased father and her mother, now 86 years old and the registered owner of the Lasca ownership stake. Dorrit and her sisters Tamara and Sharon will inherit her fortune, considered among the largest in the world.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://icelandmag.visir.is/article/new-documents-show-president-iceland-had-connection-offshore-company-tax-haven |title=New documents show that President of Iceland had connection to offshore company in tax haven |date=April 26, 2016 |work=Iceland Magazine |accessdate=May 30, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924165928/http://icelandmag.visir.is/article/new-documents-show-president-iceland-had-connection-offshore-company-tax-haven |archivedate=September 24, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Bjarni Benediktsson (born 1970)|Bjarni Benediktsson]], Iceland's finance minister and the chairman of Gunnlaugsson's coalition partner, comes from one of Iceland's wealthiest families. He confirmed that he owned 33% of Falson & Co., a Seychelles shell company founded in 2005 to purchase real estate in Dubai. It was still active in 2009, when Benediktsson was already a member of parliament with financial disclosure requirements. He said he registered the company with tax authorities, and he was not aware that it was registered in the Seychelles.<ref name =sdstorm /> Minister of the Interior [[Ólöf Nordal]] and her husband had powers of attorney for Dooley Securities S.A., an offshore company located in Panama. She said that the company was founded for her husband but was never used, so she did not think she had to disclose it.<ref name=sdstorm /> Hrólfur Ölvisson, the managing director of Gunnlaugsson's Progressive Party, says the Mossack Fonseca companies that list his name have been inactive a very long time, and were legal.<ref name=sdstorm />
Businesswoman [[Ingibjörg Stefanía Pálmadóttir|Ingibjörg Pálmadóttir]] and her husband [[Jón Ásgeir Jóhannesson]] have for several years financed their business dealings through a Panamanian company, Guru Invest, which owns shares in retailer [[Sports Direct]] through Rhapsody Investments (Europe), based in Luxembourg.<ref name=IR2>{{cite news |url=http://icelandreview.com/news/2016/04/21/second-panama-papers-leak-story-released |title=Second Panama Papers Leak Story Released |author=Alëx Elliott |work=Iceland Review Online |date=April 21, 2016 |accessdate=April 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423002631/http://icelandreview.com/news/2016/04/21/second-panama-papers-leak-story-released |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Guru Invest paid around USD 16 million to [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]] bank after it crashed to cover the debt of [[Baugur Group|Gaumur]], one of Jón Ásgeir's companies, and loaned ISK 100 million to Jón Ásgeir's company Þú Blásól through an offshore company he owns named Jovita. Asked by journalists at ''[[Kjarninn]]'' where that money came from, Ingibjörg did not reply.<ref name=IR2 /> Ingibjörg is the primary owner of the [[365 (media corporation)|365 media group]], which owns the Icelandic news outlets [[DV (newspaper)|Vísir.is]], television channel [[Stöð 2]] and radio stations [[Bylgjan]], {{Interlanguage link multi|X-ið|is}} and [[FM 957 (Icelandic Radio Station)|FM 957]], none of which seem to be reporting this disclosure.<ref name=IR2 />
==== Ireland ====
The ''[[Irish Times]]'' newspaper handled the Irish component of the leak. Prominent Irish names listed included golfer [[Pádraig Harrington]], property developer [[Sean Mulryan]] and the manager of Irish rock group [[U2]], [[Paul McGuinness]].<ref name="irelandpapers">{{Cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/panama-papers-the-irish-connections-1.2638474|title=Panama Papers: the Irish connections: Irish builders, sportsmen, bankers, solicitors, accountants listed in the leaked files|publisher=Irish Times|date=8 May 2016}}</ref> The lists also included Stanley Watson, a senior partner of Ireland's largest tax-law firm, [[Matheson (law firm)|Matheson]], who have led the creation of many of the Irish corporate tax management tools used by US multinationals in Ireland to avoid billions in US taxes.<ref name="mat">{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/retail-and-services/senior-matheson-figure-set-up-cyprus-firm-to-reduce-tax-bill-1.2596988|title=Senior Matheson figure set up Cyprus firm to reduce tax bill|publisher=Irish Times|date=4 April 2016}}</ref> The list also included Irish [[Fine Gael]] political advisor, [[Frank Flannery]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/financial-services/what-the-panama-papers-tell-us-about-ireland-1.2603444|title=What the Panama Papers tell us about Ireland|publisher=Irish Times|date=9 April 2016}}</ref>
==== Italy ==== [[File:Silvio Berlusconi in 2015.jpeg|thumb|upright|[[Silvio Berlusconi]], former Prime Minister of Italy]] On April 6, 2016, Italy's [[Judiciary of Italy|Procura of Turin]] ordered the [[Guardia di Finanza]] to investigate the 800 Italians contained in the Panama Papers' documents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/2016/04/06/news/panama_papers_procure_italiane_al_lavoro_la_guardia_di_finanza_indaga_per_riciclaggio-136999109/ |title=Panama Papers, procure italiane al lavoro. Former long-time Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]], who had been already convicted for [[tax evasion]] and expelled from the [[Italian Parliament|Parliament]], was included in the papers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lastampa.it/2016/04/14/italia/cronache/panama-papers-altri-nomi-spuntano-galliani-a-barilla-pessina-berlusconi-e-briatore-wPqiPZG7qO7fLBf2pLHfXL/pagina.html |title=Panama Papers, altri 100 nomi: spuntano Galliani, Barilla, Pessina, Berlusconi e Briatore. An investigation by ICIJ partner ''The Namibian'' found that the imprisoned mafioso [[Vito Roberto Palazzolo]] shielded his finances from Italian, Namibian and South African authorities with shell companies in the British Virgin Islands set up by a German banker in Hong Kong, Wolf-Peter Berthold, which they also used to transfer control of Palazzolo's assets to his son.<ref name=NamPal>{{cite news |url=http://www.namibian.com.na/Nujoma-link-in-Panama-Papers/39165/read#close |title=Nujoma link in 'Panama Papers' |author1=Tileni Mongudhi |author2=Ndanki Kahiurika |date=April 7, 2016 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |work=The Namibian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418042023/http://www.namibian.com.na/Nujoma-link-in-Panama-Papers/39165/read#close |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Malta ==== [[File:Konrad Mizzi.jpg|left|thumb|[[Konrad Mizzi]], former Minister for Energy and Health. Current Minister for Tourism, Malta]] The Panama Papers linked a minister in the government of Prime Minister [[Joseph Muscat]], [[Konrad Mizzi]], and the prime minister's chief of staff, [[Keith Schembri]], to shell companies in Panama. Furthermore, Mizzi's wife, Sai Mizzi Liang, who is Malta's trade envoy to China and Consul General for Malta in Shanghai, China, was also named as beneficiary, together with their children, of a trust based in New Zealand holding Mizzi's Panama shell company.
Mizzi, until 28 April 2016 Minister for Health and Energy, and currently Minister for Tourism, is listed in the Panama Papers as the owner of a Panama shell company called Hearnville Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160428/local/cabinet-reshuffle-konrad-mizzi-loses-portfolios-but-stays-in-cabinet.610356 |title=Reshuffle: Konrad Mizzi still in Cabinet, Schembri to stay put |author=Allied Newspapers Ltd |work=Times of Malta |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160501160155/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20160428/local/cabinet-reshuffle-konrad-mizzi-loses-portfolios-but-stays-in-cabinet.610356 |archivedate=May 1, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Indications in the Maltese press of Mizzi's links to an offshore trust<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/62554/konrad_mizzi_to_declare_new_zealand_family_trust#.VyYLyDB96hf |title=Konrad Mizzi to declare New Zealand family trust |work=MaltaToday.com.mt |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429202009/http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/62554/konrad_mizzi_to_declare_new_zealand_family_trust#.VyYLyDB96hf |archivedate=April 29, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> did not prevent Mizzi from being elected deputy leader for party affairs of the ruling [[Labour Party (Malta)|Labour]] Party on 25 February 2016, following a change in the party statutes to enable a sitting MP to be appointed. ==== Norway ==== The [[Norwegian Tax Administration]] expects to demand access to information from [[DNB ASA|DNB]] (Norway's largest financial services group) about approximately 30 companies formed by DNB that are owned by Norwegians, 20 of whom are living in Norway.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/panama-papers/skatteetaten-jakter-paa-30-nordmenn/a/23652023/ |title=Skatteetaten jakter på 30 nordmenn |author=Linn Johansen |work=VG |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |trans-title=The tax agency hunts for 30 Norwegians |language=Norwegian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024845/http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/panama-papers/skatteetaten-jakter-paa-30-nordmenn/a/23652023/ |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> 200 Norwegians are on the client list of Mossack Fonseca.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dn.no/etterBors/2016/04/04/1531/Panamaavslringene/-fantastisk--vre-en-brikke-i-et-stort-grensesprengende-prosjekt |title=Fantastisk å være en brikke i et stort grensesprengende prosjekt |work=www.dn.no |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |author=Mina Ghabel Lunde |language=Norwegian |trans-title=Wonderful to be a cog in a large pioneering project |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024658/http://www.dn.no/etterBors/2016/04/04/1531/Panamaavslringene/-fantastisk--vre-en-brikke-i-et-stort-grensesprengende-prosjekt |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Portugal ==== The [[ICIJ]]'s Offshore Leaks Database shows that Portugal had 246 Offshore Entities, 300 Officers, 40 Intermediaries and 175 Addresses linked to the activities described in the Mossack-Fonseca papers,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://offshoreleaks.cloud.icij.org/search?c=PRT&cat=0&e=&j=&q=&utf8=%E2%9C%93 |title=Browse by country Portugal – ICIJ Offshore Leaks Database |publisher=}}</ref> with newspapers reporting the involvement of several politicians, government officials, bankers and company managers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://leitor.expresso.pt/#library/expressodiario/09-05-2016/caderno-1/temas-principais/os-70-nomes-portugueses-nos-panama-papers-ja-publicados- |title=Impresa Digital Reader |website=leitor.expresso.pt |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813183747/http://leitor.expresso.pt/#library/expressodiario/09-05-2016/caderno-1/temas-principais/os-70-nomes-portugueses-nos-panama-papers-ja-publicados- |archivedate=August 13, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> As of May 2017, there were no criminal or judicial consequences for any of the involved.
==== Russia ==== [[File:Vladimir Putin and Arkady Rotenberg.jpeg|thumb|Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] with Russian businessman and oligarch [[Arkady Rotenberg]] ]]
The ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'', one of the newspapers participating in the project that made the papers public, described the connections of various individuals listed in them to Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]]. They quoted Nobel-winning economist [[Paul Krugman]] and US State Department documents saying that Russia is a "[[kleptocracy]]" and a "mafia state" respectively.<ref name="sd"/> The ''Süddeutsche Zeitung'' reported about $2 billion had moved through a network of companies associated with Russian firms and individuals in "just a few years" and the companies appeared to have been used for "questionable business transactions".<ref name=sd />
Putin has criticized offshore companies as "unpatriotic" on several occasions since 2011<ref name=sd>{{cite web |url=http://panamapapers.sueddeutsche.de/articles/56fec05fa1bb8d3c3495adf8/ |title=Putin's rich friends |author1=Petra Blum |author2=Frederik Obermaier |author3=Bastian Obermayer |date= |work=Panama Papers |publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421153335/http://panamapapers.sueddeutsche.de/articles/56fec05fa1bb8d3c3495adf8/ |archivedate=April 21, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and in 2013 a law was passed banning foreign bank accounts for government officials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://imrussia.org/en/politics/545-putins-foreign-asset-ban-in-action |title=Putin's Foreign Asset Ban in Action |last=Jensen |first=Donald N. |date=2013-09-04 |website=Institute of Modern Russia |language=English |access-date=2016-04-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160601060451/http://imrussia.org/en/politics/545-putins-foreign-asset-ban-in-action |archivedate=June 1, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Putin's name does not appear in any of the records released to date, but those of his associates do. Construction billionaires [[Arkady Rotenberg|Arkady]] and [[Boris Romanovich Rotenberg|Boris Rotenberg]], musician [[Sergei Roldugin]] and business magnate [[Alisher Usmanov]] are mentioned in the leaked documents,<ref name="Guardian Putin">{{cite news |title=Revealed: the $2bn offshore trail that leads to Vladimir Putin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/03/panama-papers-money-hidden-offshore |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=April 3, 2016 |first=Luke |last=Harding |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161214215121/https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/03/panama-papers-money-hidden-offshore |archivedate=December 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> as are Putin's long-standing friend, billionaire [[Gennady Timchenko]],<ref name="Guardian Putin" /> as well as his press secretary's spouse, his cousin, and former [[KGB]] colleagues,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chance |first1=Matthew |title=Putin, power and the Panama Papers |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/04/06/europe/chance-putin-panama-papers/ |work=CNN |date=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410173516/http://edition.cnn.com/2016/04/06/europe/chance-putin-panama-papers |archivedate=April 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> as well as several oligarchs connected to Mossack Fonseca shell companies.<ref name="sd" />
[[Sergei Roldugin]], a cellist with the St Petersburg orchestra who is the godfather of Putin's eldest daughter and who has been described as Putin's "best friend", appears prominently in the Panama Papers. According to the leaked papers, Roldugin acquired assets worth at least $100 million, including a 12.5% stake in Video International (Russia's largest television advertising firm),<ref name="Guardian Putin"/> companies that own stock options for some of Russia's biggest companies and the rights to loans worth hundreds of millions of dollars.<ref name=massive>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article70001162.html |title=Massive leak exposes how the wealthy and powerful hide their money |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=April 19, 2016 |publisher=[[McClatchy DC]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415213228/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/national/article70001162.html |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2008, a company controlled by Roldugin joined with several other offshore companies to help "another Putin insider" acquire control of [[Kamaz]], Russia's largest truck manufacturer, and obtain investment from German carmaker [[Daimler AG]], $250 million for 10% of Kamaz.<ref name=massive /> Sandalwood, another company in which Roldugin and other insiders have an interest was issued lines of credit between 2009 and 2012 worth $800,000 by Russian Commercial Bank (RCB) in Cyprus, then a wholly owned subsidiary of [[VTB Bank]], largely owned by the Russian state.<ref name=sd /> Panama Papers documents indicate that Roldugin companies received several loans with no collateral, or at very low interest rates, or never repaid.<ref name=sd /> In 2013, several shell companies linked to the brothers Boris and Arkady Rotenberg loaned worth about US$200 million to a company in Roldugin's network. The leaked documents do not show whether they were repaid. Shortly before the loan was granted, Arkady Rotenberg's company had been awarded the tender for the South Stream pipeline project, worth billions.<ref name=sd /> Asked about his companies,<ref name=NG>{{cite news |url=http://krug.novayagazeta.ru/12-zoloto-partituri |title=Золото партитуры |trans-title=Gold of the score |newspaper=[[Novaya Gazeta]] |location=Moscow |date=April 3, 2016 |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |language=ru |quote=Gold sheet music – Why Sergei Roldugin, a close friend of Vladimir Putin, may be deemed to be not only a virtuoso musician, but also the owner of shady offshore Empire with assets in the billions of dollars |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406043430/http://krug.novayagazeta.ru/12-zoloto-partituri |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Rodulgin said "I have to take a look and find out what I can say and what I can't", and that financial matters are "delicate".<ref name=NG/>
Putin's spokesperson [[Dmitry Peskov]] called Western reporting of the Panama Papers "Putinophobia", said that they target Putin and are part of a conspiracy against Russia orchestrated by the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the [[United States Department of State]] and others.<ref name=Putinphobia2>{{cite news |last1=Harding |first1=Luke |title=Kremlin dismisses revelations in Panama Papers as 'Putinphobia' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/04/kremlin-reaction-putin-dmitry-peskov-panama-papers-putinphobia |work=The Guardian |language=English |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 6, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405094750/http://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/04/kremlin-reaction-putin-dmitry-peskov-panama-papers-putinphobia |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Russia says Putin is main target of Panama Papers |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/04/04/russia-says-putin-main-target-panama-papers/82600272/ |work=USA TODAY |author1=Kim Hjelmgaard |author2=Anna Arutunyan |accessdate=2016-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521020202/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/04/04/russia-says-putin-main-target-panama-papers/82600272/ |archivedate=May 21, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Vladimir Putin's spokesperson blames 'Putinophobia' for Panama leak |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/panama-papers-vladimir-putins-spokesperson-blames-putinophobia-for-financial-tax-cellist-allegations-a6967796.html |work=The Independent |language=English |author=Lizzie Dearden |accessdate=2016-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510093624/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/panama-papers-vladimir-putins-spokesperson-blames-putinophobia-for-financial-tax-cellist-allegations-a6967796.html |archivedate=May 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kremlin Blasts Panama Papers As Putinophobic 'Attack' On Russia Orchestrated By CIA |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/kremlin-blasts-panama-papers-putinophobic-attack-russia-orchestrated-cia-2347912 |work=International Business Times |author=Howard Amos |accessdate=2016-05-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160514095338/http://www.ibtimes.com/kremlin-blasts-panama-papers-putinophobic-attack-russia-orchestrated-cia-2347912 |archivedate=May 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Putin denied "any element of corruption", and said his opponents are trying to destabilize Russia.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35989560 |title=Panama Papers: Putin rejects corruption allegations |agency=[[BBC News]] |date=April 7, 2016 |accessdate=April 7, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407160120/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35989560 |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Putin also said: "WikiLeaks has showed us that official people and official organs of the US are behind this."<ref name="Guardian">"[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/07/putin-dismisses-panama-papers-as-an-attempt-to-destabilise-russia Putin dismisses Panama Papers as an attempt to destabilise Russia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170107103049/https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/07/putin-dismisses-panama-papers-as-an-attempt-to-destabilise-russia |date=January 7, 2017 }}". ''[[The Guardian]].'' April 7, 2016.</ref> On 2016's annual ''[[Direct Line with Vladimir Putin]]'', he called the leaked documents "reliable" but confined his comments to Roldugin, saying that Western media did not understand that the musician has spent all his off-shore income on "musical instruments for Russia". Putin also said [[Goldman Sachs]] owned shares in the parent company of ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'', which is in fact owned by a Munich family and a German media group.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-14/putin-sees-u-s-goldman-sachs-behind-leak-of-panama-papers |title=Putin Sees U.S., Goldman Sachs Behind Leak of Panama Papers |first=world_reporter |last=Jake Rudnitsky, Rudnit; Ilya Arkhipov |website=Bloomberg.com |access-date=2016-04-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415010107/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-14/putin-sees-u-s-goldman-sachs-behind-leak-of-panama-papers |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Kremlin apologized for this "mistake".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/panama-papers/panana-papers-kremlin-apologizes-putin-s-goldman-sachs-gaffe-n556491 |title=Kremlin Apologizes for Putin's Goldman Sachs Gaffe |website=NBC News |access-date=2016-04-15 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418131924/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/panama-papers/panana-papers-kremlin-apologizes-putin-s-goldman-sachs-gaffe-n556491 |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Initially, mainstream Russian media almost entirely ignored the leak. Neither state-owned Channel 1 and Rossiya 1, nor privately owned REN-TV and NTV, mentioned the story on April 4, the day the story broke.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7325384/russian-state-media-mostly-ignore-panama-papers-putin |title=Russian State Media Mostly Ignore Panama Papers |date= |work=Billboard |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410152552/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7325384/russian-state-media-mostly-ignore-panama-papers-putin |archivedate=April 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The minimal coverage of the story ran in the middle of the night on ''Vesti TV'' and was in relation to Lionel Messi and Michel Platini.<ref name=atl>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/04/russia-panama-papers/476952/ |title=The Panama Papers in Russia |author=Tom Balmforth |date= |work=The Atlantic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204170609/http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/04/russia-panama-papers/476952/ |archivedate=December 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> An exception was the Russian opposition newspaper ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', described as "the ICIJ's Russian partner", which reported on the story both in hard copy and online.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-35959855 "Panama Papers: How Moscow and Beijing reported Panama"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426143244/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-35959855 |date=April 26, 2016 }}. [[BBC News]]. April 4, 2016.</ref>
By the end of April OCCRP published analysis of further batch of the leaked documents demonstrating a cash flow to the Rodulgin accounts from the 2007 tax theft of $230m by Moscow tax inspectors uncovered and reported by [[Sergei Magnitsky]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.occrp.org/en/panamapapers/russia-the-cellist-and-the-lawyer/ |title=Russia: The Cellist and the Lawyer – The Panama Papers |last=Radu |first=Paul |website=OCCRP |access-date=2016-04-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426223011/https://www.occrp.org/en/panamapapers/russia-the-cellist-and-the-lawyer/ |archivedate=April 26, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Spain and Royal House ==== {{See also|Corruption in Spain}} [[File:José Manuel Soria 2015b (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[José Manuel Soria]], [[Ministry of Industry (Spain)|Minister of Industry of Spain]], resigned on April 15, 2016.]]
On April 15, 2016, [[José Manuel Soria]] was forced to leave his post as acting [[Ministry of Industry (Spain)|Minister of Industry, Energy and Tourism]] when the Panama Papers revealed that he and his family had maintained several [[Offshore company|offshore societies]] on [[tax haven]]s during the previous decades.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eldiario.es/economia/ministro-Soria-papeles-Panama_0_504299816.html |title=Minister Soria is on the Panama Papers |language=Spanish |publisher=''eldiario.es'' |date=April 11, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414183546/http://www.eldiario.es/economia/ministro-Soria-papeles-Panama_0_504299816.html |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Soria initially denied this, but reports kept leaking that contradicted him. On April 14, a company came to light that he had owned on [[Jersey]] until 2002, while mayor of [[Las Palmas]]. Soria was put in a critical political position as a result of his confusing and changing explanations on the issue, and resigned the next day.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2016/04/15/571094e1ca47416b718b4633.html |title=José Manuel Soria presenta su dimisión |trans-title=José Manuel Soria hands in his resignation |language=Spanish |publisher=''El Mundo'' |date=April 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415201926/http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2016/04/15/571094e1ca47416b718b4633.html |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} </ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/panama-papers-spains-industry-minister-jose-manuel-soria-resigns-over-links-offshore-2354344 |title=Panama Papers: Spain's Industry Minister José Manuel Soria Resigns Over Links To Offshore Account |language=English |publisher=''International Business Times'' |date=April 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423040729/http://www.ibtimes.com/panama-papers-spains-industry-minister-jose-manuel-soria-resigns-over-links-offshore-2354344 |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
He is not the only prominent Spanish politician who had offshore companies.
Former [[IMF]] president [[Rodrigo Rato]], vice-president in the conservative government of prime minister [[José María Aznar]], had more than €3.6 million in two offshore companies. He has been charged by Spain with alleged tax offenses, money laundering and corruption among individuals in other cases of corruption.<ref> {{cite web|title=Rodrigo Rato aparece en los "Papeles de Panamá"|trans-title=Rodrigo Rato appears in the Panama Papers|url=http://www.abc.es/internacional/abci-rodrigo-rato-aparece-papeles-panama-201604180107_noticia.html|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418223708/http://www.abc.es/internacional/abci-rodrigo-rato-aparece-papeles-panama-201604180107_noticia.html|archivedate=April 18, 2016|df=mdy-all}} </ref> Micaela Domecq-Solís, the wife of [[Miguel Arias Cañete]], currently the European Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy and formerly the EU Minister of Agriculture, Food and Environment, also opened shell societies.
The [[Spanish Royal Family]] is also involved in this tax scandal: [[Infanta Pilar, Duchess of Badajoz|Princess Pilar of Borbón, Duchess of Badajoz]], sister of former King [[Juan Carlos I]] and aunt of the current King, [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]], had an offshore corporation for 40 years, until the abdication of her brother. She assembled a company called Delantera Financiera, in 1974, and was its president and administrator. She initially denied this when her name appeared in the Panama Papers. Her husband, who died in 1991, was secretary-general of the corporation. His son, Bruno Gomez-Acebes, is treasurer and manager of this company. The name of {{Interlanguage link multi|Amalio de Marichalar|es|3=Amalio de Marichalar y Sáenz de Tejada}}, the count of Ripalda and the brother of [[Jaime de Marichalar]], the former husband of the king's daughter, [[Elena de Borbón]], also appears.
Moreover, in a huge corruption scandal involving the royal house, [[Iñaki Urdangarin]] and his business associate in the [[Nóos case|Nóos]] foundation, were advised by Mossack Fonseca to move funds.<ref name='CICJBorbon'> {{cite web |title=The Power Players: Pilar de Borbón |url=https://projects.icij.org/panama-papers/power-players/index.html#6 |publisher=[[ICIJ]] |accessdate=April 3, 2016
