As impeachment proceedings began, it became clear that the next two people in the order of succession have been implicated in the [[Petrobras]] scandal. According to ''[[O Estado de São Paulo]]'', a company belonging to [[Eduardo Cunha]], speaker of the lower house of the legislature and a leader of the impeachment drive, has surfaced in the Panama Papers.<ref name=TTLatin>{{cite news |url=http://www.ticotimes.net/2016/04/04/officials-latin-america-linked-panama-papers |title=Officials in Latin America linked to 'Panama Papers' |author=AFP |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 29, 2016 |work=The Tico Times News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425233311/http://www.ticotimes.net/2016/04/04/officials-latin-america-linked-panama-papers |archivedate=April 25, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Rousseff herself is not mentioned in the papers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/25/world/americas/dilma-rousseff-president-of-brazil-resists-calls-for-her-resignation.html |title=Dilma Rousseff, President of Brazil, Resists Calls for Her Resignation |publisher=New York Times |date=24 March 2016 |accessdate=19 April 2016 |author=Simon Romero |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416010838/http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/25/world/americas/dilma-rousseff-president-of-brazil-resists-calls-for-her-resignation.html |archivedate=April 16, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Politicians from seven different political parties in Brazil were named as clients of Mossack Fonseca. Leaked files mention politicians from Brazil's largest party, the [[PMDB]], which broke away from President [[Dilma Rousseff]]'s coalition in 2016. Political figures from the [[PSDB]], the most prominent opposition party in the country, were also mentioned in the leaks, as well as others from the [[Democratic Labour Party (Brazil)|PDT]], PP, PSB, PSD and the PTB parties. No politicians from [[Workers' Party (Brazil)|Rousseff's party]] were mentioned in the leaks.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cascione |first1=Silvio |last2=Simon |first2=W |title=Brazil politicians linked to offshore companies in Panama leaks: paper |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-brazil-idUSKCN0X11C1 |accessdate=April 20, 2016 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=April 4, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419084505/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-panama-tax-brazil-idUSKCN0X11C1 |archivedate=April 19, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===== FIFA bribes ===== A group of Dutch journalists from the daily newspaper ''[[Trouw]]'' found evidence in the Panama Papers showing that [[TV Globo]] is cited "many times" in a money laundering investigation of the [[De Nederlandsche Bank]] which revealed that for years the media outlet conducted "irregular financial transactions" through tax havens in order to pay for broadcast rights for the [[Copa Libertadores]].<ref>[http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Brazilian-Media-Giant-Globo-Implicated-in-the-Panama-Papers-20160406-0001.html Brazilian Media Giant Globo Implicated in the Panama Papers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410094618/http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Brazilian-Media-Giant-Globo-Implicated-in-the-Panama-Papers-20160406-0001.html |date=April 10, 2016 }} by teleSUR (2016)</ref>
==== Chile ==== The head of the Chilean branch of [[Transparency International]], which campaigns against corporate secrecy, resigned when his name was linked to five firms in tax havens by the leaked documents.<ref name=ch>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21696497-huge-trove-documents-has-revealed-secrets-offshore-business-presaging-tougher |date=9 April 2016 |accessdate=20 April 2016 |title=A torrential leak: A huge trove of documents has revealed the secrets of offshore business, presaging tougher times for tax havens |publisher=The Economist |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831141724/https://www.economist.com/news/international/21696497-huge-trove-documents-has-revealed-secrets-offshore-business-presaging-tougher |archivedate=August 31, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Colombia ==== The [[National Directorate of Taxes and Customs]] launched an investigation into all 850 clients of Mossack Fonseca Colombia, a subsidiary of [[Mossack Fonseca]] that was established in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eltiempo.com/economia/sectores/colombianos-que-aparecen-en-lista-de-papeles-de-panama/16554977 |title=Colombianos que aparecen en lista de Papeles de Panamá – Sectores – ELTIEMPO.COM |author=Casa Editorial El Tiempo |date=April 4, 2016 |work=El Tiempo |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024904/http://www.eltiempo.com/economia/sectores/colombianos-que-aparecen-en-lista-de-papeles-de-panama/16554977 |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2014, Colombia had placed Panama onto its blacklist of tax havens.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.comunidadcontable.com/BancoConocimiento/N/noti_0810201401_lista_de_paraisos_fiscales_para_colombia/noti_0810201401_lista_de_paraisos_fiscales_para_colombia.asp |trans-title=List of tax havens for Colombia |date=October 23, 2014 |accessdate=April 5, 2016 |work=Legis Comunidad Contable |title=Lista de paraísos fiscales para Colombia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160522155715/http://www.comunidadcontable.com/BancoConocimiento/N/noti_0810201401_lista_de_paraisos_fiscales_para_colombia/noti_0810201401_lista_de_paraisos_fiscales_para_colombia.asp |archivedate=May 22, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The leaked documents also led Panama to move forward with the ongoing negotiations with Colombia on tax information-sharing.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/panama-tax-colombia-idUSL2N17F0WR |title=Colombia and Panama to hold new talks on tax info sharing |date=April 12, 2016 |accessdate=April 13, 2016 |work=Reuters |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160418122945/http://www.reuters.com/article/panama-tax-colombia-idUSL2N17F0WR |archivedate=April 18, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Ecuador ==== [[File:Rafael Correa in France (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|President [[Rafael Correa]] ]] Ecuadorian journalists have published the names of three current government officials, and the Panama Papers also reveal that in 2012 the Panamanian government believed that a Mossack Fonseca company the anti-corruption prosecutor was investigating for embezzlement, Orlion S.A., had been sold to president [[Rafael Correa]] Delgado and his brother Fabricio Correa in 2006.<ref name=CO>{{cite news |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/world/article73448692.html |title=Ecuador's leader demands release of Panama Papers, and learns he's in them |author1=Kevin G. Hall |author2=Vera Bergengruen |author3=McClatchy Washington Bureau |work=Charlotte Observer |date=April 22, 2016 |accessdate=April 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424112946/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/world/article73448692.html |archivedate=April 24, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Mossack Fonseca had been asked for shareholder information but did not have it, and so contacted Legalsa & Asociados, a law firm in [[Guayaquil]], Ecuador which had set up the offshore for a client.<ref name=CO /> Shortly afterwards the firm dropped the offshore due to lack of information.<ref name=CO />
Correa's cousin, [[Pedro Delgado Campana]], convicted in absentia in Ecuador for embezzlement, bought a home in North Miami Beach through a Mossack Fonseca company with his wife, who was Consul of Ecuador in Miami at the time.<ref name=MNT>{{cite news |url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/panama-papers-ecuadorian-presidents-fugitive-cousin-used-shell-firm-to-buy-north-miami-beach-home-8386183 |title=Panama Papers: Ecuadorian President's Fugitive Cousin Used Shell Firm to Buy North Miami Beach Home |author=David Minsky |date=April 14, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |work=Miami New Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424203635/http://www.miaminewtimes.com/news/panama-papers-ecuadorian-presidents-fugitive-cousin-used-shell-firm-to-buy-north-miami-beach-home-8386183 |archivedate=April 24, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Arturo Torres, investigative editor of [[El Comercio (Ecuador)|''El Comercio'']], told the [[Knight Center for Journalism in the Americas|Knight Center]] his newspaper published two stories connected to the Panama Papers:
* Grupo Ortega Trujillo offshore companies in Panama * a Chinese company, with government contracts and ties to companies that operate in tax havens
He and the rest of the six journalists from Ecuador report they have received summonses and subpoenas from little-known anticorruption agency Council of Citizen Participation and Social Control (CPCCS), demanding all documents. A scheduled hearing was postponed due to the earthquake April 16. The National Assembly's Commission of Justice has also opened an investigation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/2016/04/13/nota/5522208/comision-asamblea-ecuador-inicio-analisis-caso-papeles-panama |title=Comisión de la Asamblea de Ecuador inició análisis del caso Papeles de Panamá |date=April 13, 2016 |accessdate=May 8, 2016 |language=Spanish |publisher=El Universo |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422183747/http://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/2016/04/13/nota/5522208/comision-asamblea-ecuador-inicio-analisis-caso-papeles-panama |archivedate=April 22, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Mónica Almeida of ''[[El Universo]]'' said that the government has taken coverage of the Panama Papers as an attack on itself. Stories in the Ecuadorian media have mentioned attorney general [[Galo Chiriboga]]; [[Pedro Delgado Campaña]], the former president of the [[Central Bank of Ecuador]] and Correa' cousin; and Javier Molina, a former adviser of the Ministry of Intelligence and one of the founders of Mossack Fonseca in Quito.<ref name=harass>{{cite news |url=https://knightcenter.utexas.edu/blog/00-16990-ecuadorian-journalists-face-%E2%80%9Ccampaign-harassment%E2%80%9D-participating-investigation-panama-p |title=Ecuadorian journalists face 'campaign of harassment' for participating in the investigation of the Panama Papers |author=Silvia Higuera |publisher=Knight Foundation |date=April 21, 2016 |accessdate=May 8, 2016 }}</ref>
==== Peru ==== Two supporters of leading candidate [[Keiko Fujimori]] have undeclared interests on Mossack Fonseca companies, according to ICIJ partner ''[[OjoPúblico]]'', which said as well that three renowned chefs and Peru's largest timber company were also implicated.<ref name=TTLatin />
[[Mario Vargas Llosa]], who also has Spanish nationality, and his wife bought an offshore company through the buffer Mossack Fonseca. The couple appears linked to this from September 1, 2010, to October 6 of that year, shortly after Vargas Llosa won the [[Nobel Prize for Literature]]. After appearing linked, they denied using any tax havens.<ref>{{cite web |title=Panama Papers: Mario Vargas Llosa niega vínculos con empresa offshore |url=http://larepublica.pe/politica/757871-panama-papers-mario-vargas-llosa-es-vinculado-con-empresa-offshore |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406215622/http://larepublica.pe/politica/757871-panama-papers-mario-vargas-llosa-es-vinculado-con-empresa-offshore |archivedate=April 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Uruguay ==== Five people were arrested on April 22, on suspicion of laundering funds for a Mexican drug cartel.<ref name="ICIJuru"/> A Uruguayan investigation had been underway, but authorities decided to move because of reports in an ICIJ partner, the weekly ''[[Búsqueda]]'', that [[Gerardo González Valencia]] had used Mossack Fonseca companies to buy real estate in Uruguay. The head of the Los Cuinos cartel, his brother [[Abigael González Valencia]], is now imprisoned in Mexico and the United States has designated him a drug kingpin, as well as his brother-in-law [[Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes]], who leads the [[Jalisco New Generation Cartel]] (CJNG).<ref name=ICIJuru/>
==== Venezuela ==== Josmel Velásquez, brother of a security official under the late [[Hugo Chávez]], was arrested April 15 trying to catch a flight out of the country due to an offshore company revealed by the Panama Papers. His mother Amelis Figueroa was also arrested, but allowed to return home due to her health.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/venezuela-arrests-implicated-panama-papers-leak-38577221 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422105710/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/venezuela-arrests-implicated-panama-papers-leak-38577221 |archivedate=2016-04-22 |title=Venezuela Prosecutors Arrest 2 Named in 'Panama Papers' Leak |publisher=ABC News |agency=Associated Press |date=21 April 2016 |accessdate=22 April 2016}}</ref> Venezuelan news site [[Armando.info]] reported that Josmel's brother Adrian, a former aide to late President Hugo Chávez, had opened a shell company though Mossack Fonseca in the Republic of the Seychelles with a $50,000 deposit. Their report was based on the documents leaked from Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca.<ref name=armando> {{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-crime-idUSKCN0XI028 |title=Venezuela indicts businessman implicated in Panama Papers |date=April 20, 2016 |agency=Reuters |author1=Corina Rodriguez |author2=Brian Ellsworth |editor=Andrew Hay |accessdate=June 1, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630045624/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-crime-idUSKCN0XI028 |archivedate=June 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Velásquez was Indicted April 20.<ref name=armando />
Franklin Durán, notorious in Venezuela and Argentina for his part in ''el maletinazo'', or "suitcase scandal" involving an alleged illicit contribution from Venezuelan president [[Hugo Chavez]] to [[Christina Fernandez de Kirchner]] of $800,000 from the Venezuelan state-run oil company, PDVSA, was able to open a shell company from a jail cell in the United States, where he was serving a sentence for operating as an unregistered foreign agent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://amp.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article71909897.html|title=Venezuelan convict at center of 'suitcase scandal' didn't raise flags for Panama Papers firm|author1=Jim Wyss|author2=Nicholas Nahemas|publisher=Miami Herald|date=April 14, 2016|accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref>
===Africa===
Former South African president [[Thabo Mbeki]], head of the [[African Union]]'s panel on illicit financial flows, on April 9 called the leak "most welcome" and called on African nations to investigate the citizens of their nations who appear in the papers. His panel's 2015 report<ref name=uneca>{{cite web|url=http://www.uneca.org/sites/default/files/PublicationFiles/iff_main_report_26feb_en.pdf |title=Illicit Financial Flows: Report of the High Level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa: Commissioned by the AU/ECA Conference of Ministers of Finance, Planning and Economic Development|format=PDF}}</ref> found that Africa loses $50 billion a year due to tax evasion and other illicit practices and its 50-year losses top a trillion dollars. Furthermore, he said, the [[Seychelles]], an African nation, is the fourth most mentioned tax haven in the documents.<ref name=NWau>{{cite news |title=PANAMA PAPERS: AFRICAN UNION CALLS FOR INVESTIGATIONS |author=Conor Gaffey |date=April 11, 2016 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |work=Newsweek |url=http://www.newsweek.com/panama-papers-african-union-calls-investigations-446221 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423045728/http://www.newsweek.com/panama-papers-african-union-calls-investigations-446221 |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Algeria ==== Minister of Industry and Mines [[Abdeslam Bouchouareb]] has been sole owner of a Panamanian-registered offshore company known as Royal Arrival Corp since 2015. The company, active in Turkey, Great Britain and Algeria, is managed through Compagnie d'Etude et de Conseil (CEC), based in Luxembourg, and has an account in the Swiss [[NBAD Private Bank (Suisse) SA|NBAD Private Bank]]. CEC confirmed the ownership of Royal Arrival and said it managed the minister's inherited assets with transparency.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffpostmaghreb.com/2016/04/03/panama-papers-bouchouareb_n_9606134.html |title=Panama Papers: Bouchouareb parmi des dirigeants mondiaux possédant des sociétés offshores |publisher=HuffPost Algérie |author=Hamdi Baala |date=April 3, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415033020/http://www.huffpostmaghreb.com/2016/04/03/panama-papers-bouchouareb_n_9606134.html |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Algeria estimates it has lost 16 billion dollars offshore between 2004 and 2014, a cause for concern given the drop in the price of oil, which accounts for 95% of Algeria's external revenue.<ref name=MondePanAf>{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2016/04/04/les-africains-du-panama-2-ces-ministres-en-algerie-et-en-angola-clients-de-mossack-fonseca_4895210_3212.html |title=Les Africains du Panama (2) : ces ministres en Algérie et en Angola clients de Mossack Fonseca |author1=Joan Tilouine |author2=ICIJ |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 30, 2016}}</ref>
==== Angola ==== {{See also|Corruption in Angola|Biens mal acquis}} The Panama Papers exposed a link between an American oil company's oil concessions and several powerful politicians in Angola.<ref name=NamAn>{{cite web |url=http://www.namibian.com.na/Angolan-elite-swim-in-oil-deals/39958/read |title=Angolan elite swim in oil deals |author=Khadija Sharife |date=April 26, 2016 |accessdate=April 28, 2016 |work=The Namibian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427113832/http://www.namibian.com.na/Angolan-elite-swim-in-oil-deals/39958/read |archivedate=April 27, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to the leaked documents approximately fifteen shell companies funneled money through [[UBS]] bank accounts to elites in Portugal with direct ties to [[Helder Bataglia dos Santos]] of Escom, which describes itself as one of the largest investors in Angola and the Democratic Republic of Congo.<ref name=NamAn /> The account of one company, Markwell Inc, received and sent on over $12 million in 2008 and 2009.<ref name=NamAn />
Petroleum Minister [[José Maria Botelho de Vasconcelos]] had power of attorney for an offshore company in 2002, when he became petroleum minister after previously being employed for a number of years as an executive at [[Sonangol]],<ref name=MondePanAf /> according to the leaked documents. He denies wrongdoing.<ref name=GMafrica>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/panama-papers-reveal-african-connections/article29581445/ |title=Panama Papers reveal African connections |author=Geoffrey York |date=April 10, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=''Globe and Mail'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426010336/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/panama-papers-reveal-african-connections/article29581445/ |archivedate=April 26, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ICIJ partner ''Le Monde'' says it has seen documents that show he was the proxyholder for Medea Investments Limited, founded in [[Niue]] in 2001, and moved to Samoa five years later. The company, which issued only bearer bonds, had a capitalization of $1 million, and closed in 2009.<ref name=MondePanAf /> He has never previously been accused of corruption.<ref name=aflist />
Angola's $5 billion sovereign wealth fund, the [[Fundo Soberano de Angola]] (FSDEA), promotes itself as a vehicle of development and prosperity for Angola. The FSDEA is headed by José Filomeno de Sousa "Zenu" dos Santos, the son of President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]], who has been in power since 1979. Funded by the state-owned petroleum company [[Sonangol Group|Sonangol]], the FSDEA has critics who say that its record-keeping is murky and that it seems to engage in nepotism and cronyism.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/angola/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529034238/https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/angola/ |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=Leaks reveal extensive siphoning of $5bn Angolan sovereign wealth fund |work=#Panama Papers |publisher=ANCIR}}</ref>
==== Botswana ==== Ian Kirby, head of the Court of Appeal, owns seven holding companies in the British Virgin Islands. He has said they were intended for investment, and lost money.<ref name=aflist />
==== Republic of the Congo ==== In 2015, [[Republic of Congo|Congo]] produced 290,000 barrels of oil a day.<ref name=Mondevap /> Philia's attorney denied receiving advantageous pricing and said it only received 2.5% of Coraf oil.<ref name=Mondevap />
===== Sassou-Nguesso ===== [[File:Denis Sassou Nguesso detail DF-SC-88-01683.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Denis Sassou Nguesso]], President of Congo-Brazzaville]] Denis Christel Sassou-Nguesso is the son of [[Denis Sassou Nguesso]], in power for 32 years and re-elected in March in a disputed election. Daniel is a representative for [[Oyo, Congo|Oyo]], a member of the ruling Parti congolais du travail or [[Congolese Party of Labour]]. He is also the assistant director-general of the [[Société Nationale des Pétroles du Congo|Société nationale des pétroles du Congo]] (SNPC), and general manager of the national refinery, Coraf. According to leaked documents he had Mossack Fonseca establish a shell company in the British Virgin Islands for him named Phoenix Best Finance Ltd.
His name also appears in 2002 as a director of Geneva-based Philia SA alongside oil merchant Jean-Philippe Amvame Ndong.<ref name=MondePanAf1>{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2016/04/04/les-africains-du-panama-1-les-circuits-offshore-des-fils-de_4895102_3212.html#JWAeAK6oVt0UvEe4.99 |title=Les Africains du Panama (1): les circuits offshore des 'fils de' |author1=Joan Tilouine |author2=ICIJ |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |work=Le Monde |language=French}}</ref> He has denied all knowledge of any of these matters.<ref name=MondePanAf1 />
According to Swiss non-profit [[Erklärung von Bern|Berne Declaration]], Philia has an exclusive no-bid contract for Congolese oil exports from the Coraf refinery, and for the last three years the country has not received any payment at all for oil shipped to the refinery.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bernedeclaration.ch/media/press-release/congolese_oil_wealth_squandered_in_geneva/ |title=Congolese oil wealth squandered in Geneva |date=March 1, 2015 |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |author=Berne Declaration |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629110456/https://www.bernedeclaration.ch/media/press-release/congolese_oil_wealth_squandered_in_geneva/ |archivedate=June 29, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=DakarPhil>{{cite news |url=http://www.dakaractu.com/Congo-Une-societe-de-negoce-liee-au-fils-du-president-Sassou-detourne-des-revenus-du-petrole_a85410.html |title=Congo: Une société de négoce, liée au fils du président Sassou, détourne des revenus du pétrole |language=French |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |date=March 4, 2015 |work=Dakaractu |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602204845/http://www.dakaractu.com/Congo-Une-societe-de-negoce-liee-au-fils-du-president-Sassou-detourne-des-revenus-du-petrole_a85410.html |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===== Bruno Itoua ===== [[Bruno Itoua]] was the president's advisor on oil and director-general of the SNPC until 2005. A US federal court found that he diverted funds to fictitious companies, but he nonetheless became minister of energy. Panama Papers documents seen by ''Le Monde'' reveal he has also held the power of attorney since 2004 for Denvest Capital Strategies and Grafin Associated SA, registered by Mossack Fonseca in Panama and the British Virgin Islands.<ref name=Mondevap>{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2016/04/07/panama-papers-comment-le-petrole-congolais-s-evapore-dans-les-paradis-fiscaux_4898082_3212.html |title='Panama papers': comment le pétrole congolais s'évapore dans les paradis fiscaux |author=Joan Tilouine |date=April 7, 2016 |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |work=Le Monde |language=French}}</ref> Itoua is currently minister for scientific research.<ref name=Mondevap />
==== Democratic Republic of Congo ==== {{See also|Conflict resource|Corruption in the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Mining industry of the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} [[File:Joseph kabila.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Laurent-Désiré Kabila]]'s son and successor, [[Joseph Kabila]]]]
From 1999 to 2002, the Kabila regime "transferred ownership of at least $5 billion of assets from the state-mining sector to private companies under its control ... with no compensation or benefit for the State treasury", a United Nations investigation found.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/18/africa/looting-machine-tom-burgis-africa/ |title=Why the wealth of Africa does not make Africans wealthy |author=Kieron Monks |date=April 22, 2016 |accessdate=May 2, 2016 |work=CNN |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423205826/http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/18/africa/looting-machine-tom-burgis-africa/ |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The US [[Dodd-Frank Act]] was supposed to help bring about the end of conflict diamonds and minerals in the US. The idea was that public opinion would force divestment over time. Section 1502 does not require divestment, but does mandate disclosure.<ref name=fas /> But instead the disclosure requirement has simply meant new business opportunities for money launderers.<ref name=Dgold>{{cite news |title=Panama Papers: The DRC's Gold Standard |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/04/04/Panama-Papers-The-DRC's-Gold-Standard |author=Khadija Sharife |publisher=ANCIR |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |work=#Panama Papers}}</ref>
As recently as 2014 the UN found that 70 percent of DRC gold was sold in Dubai without any problem, while gold continued to provide important funding for both the army and armed rebel groups.<ref name=Dgold />
===== Dan Gertler and Beny Steinmetz ===== In March 2005, [[Dan Gertler]] International formed a new company, Global Enterprises Corporate (GEC), with Global Resources, owned by [[Beny Steinmetz]]. A former DRC mines minister, Simon Tuma-Waku, was "special adviser". The company formed a joint copper and cobalt mining venture with DRC agency La Générale Des Carriers et Des Mines ([[Gécamines]]), which held 25%, and GEC 75%, which they placed into an Isle of Man holding company, [[Nikanor plc]]. The [[IPO]] raised £400 million in London and the company eventually reached a [[market capitalization]] of $1.5 billion for an initial investment of $3 million.<ref name=Congomine>{{cite news |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-14-panama-papers-flag-billion-dollar-drc-rip-offs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529033348/http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-14-panama-papers-flag-billion-dollar-drc-rip-offs |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=Panama Papers flag billion-dollar DRC mining rip-offs |date=15 April 2016 |author=Barry Sergeant |publisher=Mail and Guardian |accessdate=April 24, 2016}}</ref>
* In January 2010 Gécamines revoked a joint venture contract for the [[Kolwezi tailings project|Kingamyambo Musonoi]] tailings copper project with [[First Quantum Minerals]], a Canadian company which had spent $750 million on a treatment plant at the site. * A majority stake was then sold to Highwinds Group, which paid $60 million and turned out to be owned by Gertler. * Gertler sold Camrose, another offshore company that owned Highwinds, to a Kazakhstan entity for $689 million. * A lawsuit, ''First Quantum vs Highwinds and others'', subsequently recovered more than a billion dollars.<ref name=Congomine />
Steinmetz appears in 282 leaked documents;<ref name=NamStein /> Gertler of Dan Gertler Inc, who had ties to [[Joseph Kabila]] and his closest aide, more than 200.<ref name=Congomine /> The presidential decree that ratified the agreement was issued despite the recommendation against it by the anti-corruption Lutundula Commission.<ref name=Congomine />
===== Jaynet Désirée Kabila Kyungu ===== According to the Panama Papers, Kabila's twin sister owns part of an offshore company with interests in Congo that include a part of mobile-phone company [[Vodacom#Member Companies|Vodacom Congo]]. The government called a press conference to warn journalists against printing the names of any Congolese figures that might appear in the documents.<ref name=GMafrica /> Kabila's sister, [[Jaynet Kabila|Jaynet Désirée Kabila Kyungu]] and Feruzi Kalume Nyembwe, an advisor to their late father and former president [[Laurent-Désiré Kabila]] are both directors of Keratsu Holding Limited, a company registered in [[Niue]] through Mossack Fonseca a few months after the elder Kabila's assassination.<ref name=MondePanAf /> Keratsu held 19.6% of the shares in Congolese Wireless Network, which held 49% of Vodacom Congo.<ref name=MondePanAf />
===== Lucien Ebata ===== [[Lucien Ebata]], a Kinshasa businessman, runs [[Orion Group SA]], registered in the Seychelles in 2009 by Mossack Fonseca through the Luxembourg-based Figed, according to the Panama Papers.<ref name=Mondevap /> Ebata, who receives a salary of a million dollars, does a business volume of around a billion, and counts both [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] and the [[Société nationale des pétroles du Congo]] (SNPC) among his customers.<ref name=Mondevap />
==== Dubai ==== {{See also|Conflict resource|Supply chain|Financial regulation}} In theory American<ref name=fas>{{cite web |url=https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43639.pdf |title=Conflict Minerals and Resource Extraction: Dodd-Frank, SEC Regulations, and Legal Challenges |author=Michael V. Seitzinger |author2=Kathleen Ann Ruane |publisher=Congressional Research Service |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |date=April 2, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005230338/https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43639.pdf |archivedate=October 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and European<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20150513IPR55318/Conflict-minerals-MEPs-ask-for-mandatory-certification-of-EU-importers |author=European Parliament |title=Conflict minerals: MEPs ask for mandatory certification of EU importers |date=20 May 2015 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602192752/http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/20150513IPR55318/Conflict-minerals-MEPs-ask-for-mandatory-certification-of-EU-importers |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> buyers of gold in Africa are required to review their supply chain and report any use of conflict resources, such as gold from eastern Congo. In practice the requirement is widely ignored, and an investigation by African Network of Centers for Investigative Reporting (ANCIR) found examples in the leaked Mossack Fonseca documents of anonymous shell companies doing the sourcing. For a start, most of the DRC gold winds up in Dubai by way of Uganda. Dubai's $75 billion gold industry is regulated with a very light hand by the quasi-private [[Dubai Multi Commodities Centre]] (DMCC).<ref name="Dgold" />
Kalotti, which exports about 40% of Dubai's gold, bought about $5.2 billion in gold in 2012 with little to no paperwork, according to [[Ernst & Young]] partner Amjad Rihan.<ref name=Dgold /> Rijan has said that both the DMCC and his employer squashed his concerns, and the DMCC changed its audit procedures to ensure a more favorable outcome in the future.<ref name=Dgold /> ANCIR journalists obtained records showing that Kalotti has sold "scrap gold" to other refiners including [[Valcambi]]. Leaked documents show PAMP Holding Mauritius signed an agreement with [[MKS (Switzerland)|MKS Holding BV]] and two shell companies described as its beneficial owners: Panama-based Mountside Investment and Hong Kong-based Dynamic Bonus Limited. In 2010 MKS Holdings owned 72% of a [[joint venture]] between [[MMTC Ltd.]], owned by the State of India, and Switzerland's [[PAMP (company)|PAMP]]. This joint venture does supply big multinationals like [[Apple Inc.|Apple]].<ref name=Dgold /><!-- this text not really connected up yet, commenting it out to avoid confusing reader. Please leave; it is relevant: Emirates Gold is the largest manufacturer of gold bars in Dubai. It shares an owner and a corporate structure with Swiss-based [[PAMP (company)|PAMP]]. Both are owned by a trust in the Bahamas named Sharaf, by means of holding companies in Luxembourg and the Netherlands.<ref name=Dgold /> -->
==== Egypt ==== <!-- [[File:Hosni Mubarak ritratto.jpg|thumb|upright|Former Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] ]]: commenting due to BLP concern: link between son and Hosni not demonstrated; the relationship is notable enough to mention, but picture of father possibly undue – unclear how hands on he was with family finances --> [[Alaa Mubarak]], son of former president [[Hosni Mubarak]], was cited as owning, through holding companies, real estate properties in London.<ref name=campri /> The assets of his Virgin Islands-registered firm Pan World Investments were frozen in response to a European Union order when his father stepped down in 2011 during the Arab Spring. Mossack Fonseca was fined $37,500 in 2013 for lack of due diligence. Alaa and his brother were convicted last year of embezzling state funds and still face trial for insider trading.<ref name=qAf>{{cite news |url=http://qz.com/653937/africa-loses-more-money-to-illicit-financial-flows-than-it-receives-in-foreign-aid/ |title=Africa loses more money to illicit financial flows than it receives in foreign aid |author=Lily Kuo |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=Quartz |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417060158/http://qz.com/653937/africa-loses-more-money-to-illicit-financial-flows-than-it-receives-in-foreign-aid/ |archivedate=April 17, 2016 |df=}}</ref>
Egyptian businessmen Mohamed Abu El-Enein, [[Bahgat Group|Ahmed Bahgat]], [[Ashraf Marwan]], Ibrahim Kamal, Mohamed Nosseir, [[Mohamed Mansour (businessman)|Mohamed Mansour]], [[Ghabbour Group|Raouf Ghabbour]], and Mohamed Al-Maghraby are all named in the leaked documents, as well as the Orascom Development Holding company, headed by [[Samih Sawiris]], and also the [[Bank of Alexandria]], [[Banque Misr]], and [[Banque du Caire]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/04/04/panama-papers-expose-the-mubaraks-tycoons-and-banks/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529034141/http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/04/04/panama-papers-expose-the-mubaraks-tycoons-and-banks/ |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=Panama Papers expose the Mubaraks, tycoons and banks |author=Abdel Razek Al-Shuwekhi |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=''Daily News Egypt''}}</ref>
Former Sudanese President [[Ahmed al-Mirghani]] was a client of Mossack Fonseca also.<ref name=dabanga /> Al-Mirghani lived in Egypt after the 1989 coup that ended his presidency and was active in the [[Democratic Unionist Party (Sudan)|Democratic Unionist Party]].<ref name=dabanga /> Orange Star Corporation bought a long-term lease in a tony London neighborhood near Hyde Park for $600,000 the same year al-Mirghani created it, and at the time of his death held assets worth $2.72 million.<ref name=dabanga />
==== Gabon ==== {{See also|Biens mal acquis}} Every Ramadan he fed 500 people; he financed about 20 pilgrimages to Mecca every year. Described as a billionaire, Seydou Kane holds diplomatic passports from Senegal, Gabon and Mali. The protocol officer of the Senegalese Embassy in Paris was waiting for him when his plane landed at [[Charles de Gaulle Airport|Roissy-Charles-de-Gaulle]] in November 2015. But Kane, a close associate of the Gabonese ruling family, was questioned and jailed in [[Nanterre]] for ten hours by anti-corruption agents in connection with an investigation opened in July 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2015/11/18/gabon-l-associe-de-l-ancien-directeur-de-cabinet-d-ali-bongo-interpelle-a-roissy_4812614_3212.html |title=Gabon : l'associé du directeur de cabinet d'Ali Bongo interpellé à Roissy |work=Le Monde Afrique |date=November 11, 2015 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |language=French |author1=Simon Piel |author2=Joan Tilouine}}</ref>
In January 2013 Kane was briefly questioned while in transit to Miami at [[Le Bourget]] by French authorities whose curiosity was piqued by €2.5 million cash he had on his person.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dakaractu.com/Corruption-sur-fond-de-blanchiment-de-capitaux-Tracfin-ferre-le-Senegalo-Malien-Seydou-Kane-et-le-Dircab-d-Ali-Bongo_a94593.html |title=Corruption sur fond de blanchiment de capitaux : Tracfin ferre le Sénégalo-Malien, Seydou Kane, et le Dircab d'Ali Bongo |date=August 4, 2015 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |work=Dakaractu |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603080631/http://www.dakaractu.com/Corruption-sur-fond-de-blanchiment-de-capitaux-Tracfin-ferre-le-Senegalo-Malien-Seydou-Kane-et-le-Dircab-d-Ali-Bongo_a94593.html |archivedate=June 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
According to Senegalese daily ''Libération'', the money-laundering unit [[Tracfin]] became interested in 2006 in a €300,000 payment from Groupe Marck, a French company specializing in military uniforms and anti-riot gear, to a Monaco-based entity called Citp. Citp was managed by Kane, a close friend of the president's chief of staff, Maixent Accrombessi, himself held in Paris and interrogated in August 2015. French officials wanted to ask Accrombessi about a contract between Marck and the Gabonese Ministry of the Interior for €7 million. The head of Marck, Philippe Belin, was also held and questioned. The investigation was assigned to {{Interlanguage link multi|Roger Le Loire|fr}}, who also conducted the so-called "ill-gotten goods" investigation, which targeted a number of African leaders including the father and predecessor of [[Ali Bongo Ondimba]], the current president of Gabon.<ref name=mal>{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2015/09/15/l-encombrant-bras-droit-d-ali-bongo_4757894_3212.html |title=L'encombrant bras droit d'Ali Bongo |author1=Cyril Bensimon |author2=Christophe Châtelot |author3=Joan Tilouine |author4=Simon Piel |language=French |work=LE MONDE |date=September 15, 2015}}</ref>
Mossack Fonseca opened two holding companies for Kane in 2013 and 2014: Maxi Gold International Limited and Smart Key LTD, which according to their paperwork traded in sundries on the one hand and gym equipment on the other.<ref>{{cite news |title=Les juteuses affaires au Panama de Seydou Kane |language=French |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/mali/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529034044/https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/mali/ |archivedate=2016-05-29 |author1=David Dembele |author2=ANCIR |author3=Consortium International du Journalisme d'Investigation (ICIJ) |work=#Panama Papers}}</ref>
==== Ghana ==== [[File:President John Kufuor - Ghana.jpg|thumb|[[John Kufuor|John Agyekum Kufuor]], former President of [[Ghana]]]] John Addo Kufuor, son of [[John Kufuor|John Agyekum Kufuor]], had Mossack Fonseca manage his [[Charitable trust|trust]] starting in 2001 when his father took office. The trust held $75,000 in a bank account in Panama; his mother was also a beneficiary. He was linked to two other offshore companies also registered during his father's term. They are now inactive.<ref name= NWau /><ref name=qAf />
Kojo Annan, son of former Secretary-General of the United Nations [[Kofi Annan]], appears with Laolu Saraki, the son of the late Nigerian senator [[Abubakar Olusola Saraki]], as shareholders in Blue Diamond Holding Management Corp, registered by Mossack Fonseca in the British Virgin Islands in 2002.<ref name=MondePanAf1 /> The two were directors of Sutton Energy Ltd, also registered in the British Virgin Islands in 2002, then transferred to Samoa.<ref name=MondePanAf1 /> In 2015, Annan used another shell company first registered in the British Virgin Islands, then transferred to Samoa, to purchase an apartment in London for $500,000.<ref name=MondePanAf1 />
==== Guinea ==== {{See also|Biens mal acquis|Corruption in Guinea}} In 2008–2009, the Beny Steinmetz Group Resources ([[Beny Steinmetz#Beny Steinmetz Group Resources|BSGR]]) and its owner [[Beny Steinmetz]] paid just $165 million for the mining rights to the northern portion of [[Simandou mine]], located in the [[Nzérékoré Region|Nzérékoré]] region of Guinea's interior. Soon after, he sold 51 percent of the rights to [[Vale (mining company)|Vale]] for $2.5 billion. [[Rio Tinto Group|Rio Tinto]], which had previously held the concession, had invested $450 million into infrastructure at the site.<ref name=guiStein>{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/04/04/Panama-Papers-Steinmetz-Guinea-deal-pried-open |title=Steinmetz Guinea deal pried open: Leaked documents pry open the corporate structure of companies involved in a mining rights scandal in Guinea |author=Khadija Sharife |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=May 9, 2016 |publisher=Times Live |work=Panama Papers |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504085959/http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/04/04/Panama-Papers-Steinmetz-Guinea-deal-pried-open |archivedate=May 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Global Witness says BSGR in fact paid nothing for the rights, and the $165 million represents BSGR's self-reported investment in improvements at the site. It adds that either way BSGR's profit exceeded the national budget of Guinea.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.globalwitness.org/en/archive/damning-video-and-contracts-show-bsgr-was-lying-guinea-mining-scandal/ |title=DAMNING VIDEO AND CONTRACTS SHOW BSGR WAS LYING IN GUINEA MINING SCANDAL |publisher=Global Witness |author1=Daniel Balint-Kurti |author2=Simon Taylor |date=April 19, 2013 |accessdate=May 9, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405111639/https://www.globalwitness.org/en/archive/damning-video-and-contracts-show-bsgr-was-lying-guinea-mining-scandal/ |archivedate=April 5, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
US authorities say that Steinmetz paid [[Mamadie Touré]] $5.3 million for her help in obtaining the concession from her husband [[Lansana Conté]], president of Guinea, shortly before he died.<ref name=aflist>{{cite news |author1=Abu-Bakarr Jalloh |author2=Friederike Müller-Jung |title=African public officials named in Panama Papers |url=http://www.dw.com/en/african-public-officials-named-in-panama-papers/a-19163446 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=May 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508171211/http://www.dw.com/en/african-public-officials-named-in-panama-papers/a-19163446 |archivedate=May 8, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to Global Witness, an offshore company belonging to Touré, Matinda, received a payment of $2.4 million from a company named Pentler Holdings. Several more payments were promised as well as 5% of [[Beny Steinmetz#Beny Steinmetz Group Resources|BSGR]] shares in Simandou. Pentler owned 17.65% of BSGR Guinea.<ref name=guiStein />
Guinean President [[Alpha Condé]] launched an investigation after he was elected in 2010. Separately, so did the US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the US justice department, suspecting violations of the [[Foreign Corrupt Practices Act]]. In August 2014 Mossack Fonseca received a [[Tax Information Exchange Agreement]] (TIEA) notice from the US government inquiring into ownership of Pentler and two other BSGR companies administered by Mossack Fonseca's Geneva office. However, the president of Pentler's financial management firm, Menachem Eitan, was a fugitive from the US SEC facing charges over a $55 million Ponzi scheme.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/20/business/20trader.html?_r=0 |title=Government Accuses 6 Men of $55 Million Offshore Fraud |author=Michael J. de la Merced |publisher=New York Times |date=October 20, 2007 |accessdate=May 9, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510083340/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/20/business/20trader.html?_r=0 |archivedate=May 10, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Guinea's Mines Minister Mohamed Lamine Fofana said in 2012 that BSGR "didn't follow the law".<ref name=guiStein />
==== Ivory Coast ==== Jean-Claude N'Da Ametchi, an advisor to former president [[Laurent Gbagbo]], who refused to accept that he lost an election in 2010, is also mentioned in the leaked documents.<ref name=MondePanAf /> The European Union sanctioned banker N'Da Ametchi in 2011 for helping to finance the Gbagbo regime.<ref name=MondePanAf /> His offshore company, Cadley House Ltd, was registered in the [[Seychelles]] with bearer bonds and a bank account in Morocco.<ref name=MondePanAf /> N'Da Ametchi sent email in 2011 to the Geneva office of Mossack Fonseca, naming the Geneva bank Pasche financial managers of the company.<ref name=MondePanAf /> In September 2012 he acted as sole director to request they transfer its registration to Abidjan. Neither Mossack Fonseca nor the banks mentioned the European sanctions; these were eventually lifted in 2012.<ref name=MondePanAf /> The company was apparently still active in 2015, according to documents seen by ''Le Monde''.<ref name=MondePanAf /> He is currently an advisor to former prime minister [[Charles Konan Banny]], who lost the October 2015 presidential election.<ref name=MondePanAf />
==== Kenya ==== Former Deputy Chief Justice [[Kalpana Rawal]] was a director or shareholder in four holding companies and was active in two after she took office. Her husband owns another seven. The companies were used for real estate transactions in Britain. Rawal and her husband were shareholders and directors of Highworth Management Services, where Ajay Shah, a former director of Trust Bank, was also a shareholder and director. The Central Bank of Kenya ordered Shah's assets auctioned to repay depositors after Trust Bank collapsed, but he went into hiding and the assets have not been recovered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nation.co.ke/news/Rawal-among-high-profile-Kenyans-with-firms-in-tax-havens/-/1056/3144804/-/13ux1ad/-/index.html |title=Deputy CJ Rawal among high-profile Kenyans with firms in tax havens: Deputy Chief Justice Kalpana Rawal and her family linked to 11 shell companies in a UK tax haven. |author=Jacqueline Kubania |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |work=Daily Nation |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420101950/http://www.nation.co.ke/news/Rawal-among-high-profile-Kenyans-with-firms-in-tax-havens/-/1056/3144804/-/13ux1ad/-/index.html |archivedate=April 20, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Morocco ==== [[Mounir Majidi]], personal secretary of King [[Mohammed VI]] was designated in March 2006 as the representative of SMCD Limited created in 2005 through Geneva financial advisor Dextima Conseils. According to the ICIJ, through SMCD Majidi bought the "Aquarius W", a 1930s-era luxury sailboat, which was then registered in Morocco as "El Boughaz", belonging to the king. SMCD, according to the ICIJ, also made a loan to a Luxembourg company, Logimed Investissements Co SARL, for which details are not available. Following this loan, SMCD was liquidated in 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.yabiladi.com/articles/details/43614/panama-papers-maroc-majidi-coeur.html |title=Panama Papers: Le Maroc et Majidi au cœur des fuites sur les sociétés offshores |language=French |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 25, 2016 |work=Yabiladi |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415181857/http://www.yabiladi.com/articles/details/43614/panama-papers-maroc-majidi-coeur.html |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Namibia ==== {{See also|Corruption in Namibia}} [[File:Sam Nujoma.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Sam Nujoma]], former President of [[Namibia]]]] Diamond Ocean Enterprises, a Mossack Fonseca entity set up in 2005, reported its purpose as financial consulting to a Namibian diamond manufacturer and polisher.<ref name=NamPal /> According to the law firm's records, Deutsche Investment Consultants (Asia) Limited, a Mossack Fonseca company set up in the British Virgin Islands for the now-imprisoned Mafioso Vito Palazzolo by Wolf-Peter Berthold, a German banker based in Hong Kong, is a director of the firm. Its shareholders include Peter von Palace Kolbatschenko, Palazzolo's son, Berthold, and Giovanni Agusta.<ref name=NamPal />
Also in 2005, Zacharias (Zacky) Nujoma, youngest son of [[Sam Nujoma]], set up two holding companies, Avila Investments and Marbella Investments, and licensed them to buy and cut diamonds. Shortly afterwards 90% of the stock was transferred to Diamond Ocean.<ref name=NamPal /> In 2006 Nujoma established Ancash Investments, which obtained seven exclusive uranium prospecting licenses.<ref name=NamPal /> Palazzolo loaned the company US$10 million.<ref name=NamPal /> Canadian mining company announced it would partner with Ancash in its uranium contracts and said it based its decision in part on Ancash's strong international support in Natural Earth International Ltd. of Hong Kong.<ref name=NamPal /> Natural Earth is another Deutsche Investment company.<ref name=NamPal />
==== Nigeria ==== {{See also|Corruption in Nigeria}}
"Corrupt officials have stolen $150 billion from Nigeria in the last 10 years," said Nigerian President [[Muhammadu Buhari]] said April 7, 2016. He added that he planned to ask United States President Barack Obama for help.
===== Bukola and Toyin Saraki ===== President of the Nigerian Senate [[Bukola Saraki]] was found, through the Panama Papers leak, to have ties to at least four offshore companies he failed to declare to the Code of Conduct Bureau as Nigerian law requires.<ref name=Toyin>{{cite news |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-19-panama-papers-may-strengthen-case-against-powerful-nigerian-leader |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529033121/http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-19-panama-papers-may-strengthen-case-against-powerful-nigerian-leader |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=Panama Papers may strengthen case against powerful Nigerian leader |author1=Emmanuel Mayah |author2=Joshua Olufemi |date=April 19, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=''Mail and Guardian''}}</ref> His wife Toyin also had shell companies listed in her name in the Mossack Fonseca documents:<ref name=Toyin /> Girol Properties Ltd, Sandon Development Limited and *Landfield International Developments Ltd. Saraki has said that the assets in these holding companies belong to his wife's family and therefore he was not required to report them. ANCIR dismisses this because:
# His close friend and aide is a shareholder in Sandon Development. # He has previously described himself, both in correspondence and in legal documents, as the shareholder of the [[Belgravia]] property owned by Sandon Development.<ref name=MGnot /> # Toyin had her lawyers send a letter to ICIJ denying ownership of Girol Properties.
However, leaked documents do link her to the firm. But a handwritten note suggests Mossack Fonseca was aware that she was a nominee director.<ref name=MGnot>{{cite news |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-19-offshore-assets-belong-to-nigerian-senate-president-not-wife |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160507054731/http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-19-offshore-assets-belong-to-nigerian-senate-president-not-wife |archivedate=2016-05-07 |title=Offshore assets belong to Nigerian Senate president, not wife |date=April 19, 2016 |author1=Emmanuel Mayah |author2=Joshua Olufemi |work=Mail & Guardian |accessdate=April 2, 2016}}</ref>
===== Aliko Dangote ===== [[Aliko Dangote]], chief executive of the [[Dangote Group]], is tied in the leaked documents to four offshore companies, and to as many as 13 if his family and business associates are included. Dangote, with an estimated $17 billion worth, is currently involved in the construction of a $14 billion oil refinery in Lagos.<ref name=Dangote>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/panama-papers-nigerian-aliko-dangote-africas-richest-man-facing-scrutiny-445477 |title=PANAMA PAPERS: NIGERIAN ALIKO DANGOTE, AFRICA's RICHEST MAN, FACING SCRUTINY |author=Conor Gaffey |date=April 8, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422044227/http://www.newsweek.com/panama-papers-nigerian-aliko-dangote-africas-richest-man-facing-scrutiny-445477 |archivedate=April 22, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===== James Ibori ===== Former [[Delta State]] governor [[James Ibori]] is also mentioned in the leak.<ref name=Dangote /> Ibori pleaded guilty in London in 2012 to siphoning $75 million out of Nigeria while he was in office from 1999–2007.<ref name="Power Players" /> All charges against him in Nigeria had been dropped in Nigeria following an election.<ref name=FTIbo>{{cite news |date=December 17, 2009 |title=Charges dropped against Nigerian politician |author=Tom Burgis |work=Financial Times |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/cbe8c71c-eb37-11de-bc99-00144feab49a,Authorised=false.html?siteedition=uk&_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2Fcbe8c71c-eb37-11de-bc99-00144feab49a.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&classification=conditional_standard&iab=barrier-app#axzz46ulbhPTo |accessdate=April 26, 2016}}</ref> Ibori was sentenced to 13 years. Mossack Fonseca, the registered agent for his four offshore entities, received a request in 2008 for information about his accounts from British Crown Prosecutors. His family's Julex Foundation was the shareholder in Stanhope Investments, a company incorporated in 2003 on the island of [[Niue]], to which he funneled millions of dollars so he could buy a private jet.<ref name="pulseJI">{{cite news |title=Ex-Governor, James Ibori named among officials with hidden offshore assets |url=http://pulse.ng/local/panama-papers-ex-governor-james-ibori-named-among-officials-with-hidden-offshore-assets-id4879207.html |accessdate=18 May 2016 |last1=Sotubo |first1=Jola |agency=Pulse |publisher=Pulse NG |date=4 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520134859/http://pulse.ng/local/panama-papers-ex-governor-james-ibori-named-among-officials-with-hidden-offshore-assets-id4879207.html |archivedate=May 20, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The United Kingdom returned £6.8 million to Nigeria from funds it had seized from accounts determined to have belonged to Ibori.<ref name="pulseJI"/><ref name="UKpules">{{cite news |last1=Soutubo |first1=Jola |title=UK To Return Ex-Governor's N1.7BN Loot |url=http://pulse.ng/news/james-ibori-uk-to-return-ex-governor-s-n1-7bn-loot-id3249201.html |accessdate=18 May 2016 |agency=Pulse |publisher=Pulse NG |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616232021/http://pulse.ng/news/james-ibori-uk-to-return-ex-governor-s-n1-7bn-loot-id3249201.html |archivedate=June 16, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The anti-corruption taskforce of the [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] government, the [[Economic and Financial Crimes Commission]], questioned at the time whether the [[Umaru Musa Yar'Adua|Yar'Adua]] administration has refrained or was loath to pursue members of the Nigerian elite suspected of corruption, including leading financiers of the ruling party, or those like Ibori who supported had their election.
===== David Mark ===== Former Senate President David Mark was also listed as owner of eight shell companies in the leaked Panama Papers:<ref>{{cite news |url=http://pulse.ng/local/frankly-speaking-with-jola-sotubo-panama-papers-will-expose-more-nigerians-id4886802.html |title=Panama Papers will expose more Nigerians |date=July 21, 2015 |accessdate=May 1, 2016 |author=Jolo Sobutu |work=pulse.ng |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512004902/http://pulse.ng/local/frankly-speaking-with-jola-sotubo-panama-papers-will-expose-more-nigerians-id4886802.html |archivedate=May 12, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Sikera Overseas S.A., Colsan Enterprises Limited, Goldwin Transworld Limited, Hartland Estates Limited, Marlin Holdings Limited, Medley Holdings Limited, Quetta Properties Limited and Centenary Holdings Limited.
===== Hakeem Belo-Osagie ===== A portion of the wealth owned by former Chairman of the United Bank for Africa (UBA), [[Hakeem Belo-Osagie]], is domiciled in trusts and shell companies in some notorious tax havens around the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title = #PanamaPapers: Secret Assets Of Etisalat Chairman, Hakeem Belo-Osagie, Uncovered In Tax Haven |url= http://saharareporters.com/2016/05/02/panamapapers-secret-assets-etisalat-chairman-hakeem-belo-osagie-uncovered-tax-haven|website = saharareporters.com|accessdate = 2018-01-15}}</ref>
==== Rwanda ==== The government of Rwanda uses an offshore company to lease a private jet for its senior politicians.<ref name=GMafrica /> Leaked documents show that Brigadier-General [[Emmanuel Ndahiro]], using a London address, become a director of a British Virgin Islands company, Debden Investments Ltd. in 1998, owner of a jet aircraft. Ndahiro, a close advisor of president [[Paul Kagame]], was then spokesman for Kagame's military.<ref name=GMafrica /> According to the Panama Papers the owner of the company was Hatari Sekoko, who ran a number of real estate and hotel ventures such as the Marriott in Kigali.<ref name=MondePanAf />
==== Senegal ====
===== Karim Wade ===== {{See also|Karim Wade}} [[File:Karim Wade.jpg|thumb|upright|Senegalese politician [[Karim Wade]] ]] <!-- this material draws heavily on the exclusive reporting of the French-language online news site Ouestaf as part of the year-long investigation of journalists world-wide into the data contained in the Panama Papers --> ICIJ partner Ouestaf.com was able to establish through the Panama Papers the existence of secret contracts between and [[DP World]] FZE (DP)and Mamadou Pouye, the [[bribery]] codefendant of [[Karim Wade]], son of former prime minister [[Abdoulaye Wade]]. This information was not available at their trial; Ouestaf confirmed their financial ties to the corporation for the first time during the Panama Papers investigation.<ref name="OuPiste"/> <!-- this material from Karim Wade article on French wikipedia start --> Wade was sentenced in 2015 to a six-year prison term by the Cour de répression de l'enrichissement illicite (Crei), a specialized anti-corruption court.<ref name="OuPiste"/> Wade was accused of illegally amassing assets of more than $240 million; and his childhood friend Pouye was sentenced to five years for allegedly helping him.<ref name="OuPiste"/> Both denied wrongdoing and the United Nations and Amnesty International said their rights had been violated at trial.<ref> {{cite web |title=Karim Wade And Mamadou Pouye Named In The Panama Papers Scandal! |url=http://www.freedomnewspaper.com/karim-wade-mamadou-pouye-named-panama-papers-scandal |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409095013/http://www.freedomnewspaper.com/karim-wade-mamadou-pouye-named-panama-papers-scandal/ |archivedate=April 9, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Ouestaf's investigation did not address the legality of their trial. It did conclude that they had succeeded in tracing a payment to Pouye's oversea shell company from a subsidiary of DP.
Wade remains a member of the [[Senegalese Democratic Party]] (PDS) and is still the PDS candidate for the 2017 presidential election.<!-- this material from Karim wade article on French wikipedia stop -->
Mossack Fonseca documents show that Pouye owned three offshore companies, Seabury Inc, Regory Invest and Latvae Inc.<ref name=OuPiste/>
* Through Seabury, a consulting contract worth €7.2 million with [[DP World]] materialized.<ref name=OuPiste/> * A second contract for 2013–2015 was to focus on DP's African holdings, and would have paid Wade and Puye $3 million at signing;<ref name=OuPiste/> however the pair were arrested.<ref name=OuPiste/>
Seabury seems to have been set up solely for doing business with DP World. It was started in 2008, a year after Senegal signed a contract with DP World for rights to the container terminal at the [[Autonomous Port of Dakar]].<ref name=OuPiste/> In April 2009 Wade became minister of international cooperation, of territorial development, air transport and infrastructure, which he remained until his father's defeat by [[Macky Sall]] in the 2012 election.<ref name=OuPiste/> Regory Invest acted as a Seabury subcontractor, receiving €65,000 euros a month, according to the documents.<ref name=OuPiste/>
According to ''Ouestaf'' the documents make it clear that while Crei investigators were interested in the funds in Pouye's Monaco account, they did not know that their source was an offshore account he created himself.<ref name=OuPiste/> The two contracts prove that there was in fact a relationship between the defendants and [[DP World]]. Investigator Papa Alboury Ndao told the court in February{{when|date=May 2016}} that he had discovered two payments of $13 million each from a subsidiary of DP World FZE to a Singapore bank account belonging to Karim Wade. However the bank in Singapore refused to cooperate and Ndao was forced to drop that line of inquiry.<ref name=OuPiste/>
===== Others ===== Mossack Fonseca opened several offshore companies for multinationals. For example: Anglogold, owner of Anglogold Investments Senegal Ltd et Anglogold Exploration Senegal Ltd (both based in the British Virgin Islands).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/senegal-wade/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529033915/https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/senegal-wade/ |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=et sociétés offshore : sur la piste des fonds de Karim Wade? |author=ANCIR |work=#Panama Papers |accessdate=May 2, 2016}}</ref>
Senegalese architect Pierre Atepa Goudiaby, a special advisor to former president [[Abdoulaye Wade]], is also mentioned in the leaked documents. The Swiss law firm Fidinam SA had Mossack Fonseca open the offshore Atepa Engineering Corp en 2006, the same year Goudiaby opened his Paris office on the Champs-Elysées.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/senegal-goudaiby/ |title=ces autres pontes sénégalais titulaires de sociétés offshore |author=ANCIR |work=#PanamaPapers |accessdate=May 4, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415093635/http://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/senegal-goudaiby/ |archivedate=April 15, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==== Sierra Leone ==== {{See also|Mining in Sierra Leone|United Nations Security Council Resolution 1306}} The ICIJ investigation traces out many levels of offshore holdings in multiple countries related to the business dealings of [[Beny Steinmetz]], with many serious findings such as a request that Mossack Fonseca backdate the revocation of a power of attorney.<ref name=NamStein>{{cite news |url=http://www.namibian.com.na/Sierra-Leone's-flawed-diamond-trade/39957/read |title=Sierra Leone's flawed diamond trade |author1=Khadija Sharife |author2=Silas Gbandia |date=April 26, 2016 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510111253/http://www.namibian.com.na/Sierra-Leone's-flawed-diamond-trade/39957/read |archivedate=May 10, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Mossack Fonseca records show that Sierra Leone diamond exporter Octea, based in the British Virgin Islands with the Steinmetz family as its beneficiaries, is wholly owned by Guernsey-based BSGR Resources, linked to a bribery scandal in Guinea. Foundations in Switzerland and Liechtenstein, among them Nysco and Balda, own BSGR. In 2007, one of Nysco's bank accounts contained $27.7 million.
Steinmetz, who has a personal fortune of $6 billion, supplies diamonds to [[Tiffany & Co.|Tiffany]] and [[DeBeers]] and is Sierra Leone's largest private investor. Yet, according to a detailed report in ''The Namibian'', his Octea subsidiary owes, among other debts, property taxes of $700,000 to the city of [[Koidu]]. These unpaid taxes are discounted, according to mayor [[Saa Emerson Lamina]], because Octea promised a 5% profit−sharing agreement, and payment 1% of its annual profit to a community development fund, but it did not do this either.<ref name=NamStein />
Octea's subsidiary, Koidu Holdings, obtained the mine for $28 million, which was supposed to be a deposit, in 2002. Fighting had stopped in Sierra Leone, and the mine had previously been held and worked by South African firm Branch Energy, in payment for the services of its parent company, [[Executive Outcomes]], "effectively...a military battalion for hire,"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/daily/oct99/sierra16.htm |title=Diamond Hunters Fuel Africa's Brutal Wars |author=James Rupert |date=October 16, 1999 |publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=May 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510210155/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/daily/oct99/sierra16.htm |archivedate=May 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> against rebel fighters in the area. Steinmetz has since put $300 million into the project.<ref name=bb />
According to reporting by the African Network of Centers for Investigative Reporting (ANCIR), the company produces 60–90% of Sierra Leone's diamond exports, and in some months between 2012 and 2015 exported more than US$330 million in rough diamonds.<ref name=NamStein /> Octea owes US$150 million in unpaid loans.<ref name=NamStein /> Although government records show taxes paid by other diamond companies, none are listed for Octea.
The National Mineral Agency (NMA) until 2005 valued diamonds for export using a price book based on 1996 figures. Companies also often seek to minimize the value of their diamond exports to reduce taxes and move profits abroad. Once transferred to a subsidiary elsewhere where their value is not taxed, the same diamonds are frequently worth more.<ref name=NamStein />
Diamonds from Koidu average $330 a carat, roughly 50% more than De Beers's Jwaneng mine in Botswana, the world's biggest. Tiffany has first pick of some of the best stones mined at Koidu and the remainder are sold to other trade buyers, according to ''Bloomberg''.<ref name=bb>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-12/was-billionaire-steinmetz-betrayed-by-his-ceo-over-diamond-mine- |title=Was Billionaire Steinmetz Betrayed by CEO Over Diamond Mine? |work=Bloomberg |accessdate=May 8, 2016 |date=November 11, 2016 |author1=Thomas Biesheuvel |author2=Jesse Riseborough |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160411202637/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-12/was-billionaire-steinmetz-betrayed-by-his-ceo-over-diamond-mine- |archivedate=April 11, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
According to the [[World Bank]], Sierra Leone for a long time based its growth forecasts on the success of two companies, one of which was Octea parent BSGR<ref name=NamStein />
==== South Africa ==== Two men linked to Fidentia, a South African asset management company that looted 1.2 billion rand<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rdm.co.za/business/2016/04/04/panama-papers-reveal-how-fidentia-money-was-stashed-overseas |title=Panama papers reveal how Fidentia money was stashed overseas |publisher=''Rand Daily Mail'' |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |author=TMG Digital |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414202803/http://www.rdm.co.za/business/2016/04/04/panama-papers-reveal-how-fidentia-money-was-stashed-overseas |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> from pension funds meant to provide for 46,000 widows and orphans of mineworkers,<ref name=Brown>{{cite web |url=http://www.globalpost.com/article/6755600/2016/04/05/how-panama-papers-are-linked-one-south-africas-biggest-frauds |title=The role Mossack Fonseca played in one of South Africa's biggest frauds |author=Erin Conway-Smith |date=April 6, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=''Global Post'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419102415/http://www.globalpost.com/article/6755600/2016/04/05/how-panama-papers-are-linked-one-south-africas-biggest-frauds |archivedate=April 19, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> had accounts with Mossack Fonseca, which was willing to help hide the money even after South Africa made their names public.<ref name=Brown /> The former chief executive of Fidentia, J. Arthur Brown, was sentenced in 2014 to concurrent 15-year sentences.<ref name=Brown /> The FBI arrested one man, Steven Goodwin, in Los Angeles in 2008. Sent back to South Africa, Goodwin was sentenced to 10 years in prison for fraud and money laundering.<ref name=ICIJgiant>{{cite news |url=https://panamapapers.icij.org/20160403-panama-papers-global-overview.html |title=Giant Leak of Offshore Financial Records Exposes Global Array of Crime and Corruption |date=April 3, 2016 |accessdate=April 24, 2016 |publisher=ICIJ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423065627/https://panamapapers.icij.org/20160403-panama-papers-global-overview.html |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The other, Graham Maddock, was also later jailed in South Africa for fraud.
[[Khulubuse Zuma]], nephew of South African President [[Jacob Zuma]], has links in the documents to an offshore company with oil interests in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. He has denied any wrongdoing.<ref name=GMafrica /> According to leaked documents President Zuma also has ties to an oil mining deal between a British Virgin Islands-based oil company, Caprikat Limited, and Joseph Kabila, President of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and helped Caprikat obtain oil fields in the DRC then sent his nephew to the DRC to run the firm.<ref name=aflist />
==== Sudan ==== Former President [[Ahmed al-Mirghani]] surfaced as a client of Mossack Fonseca.<ref name=dabanga>{{cite news |url=https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/former-sudanese-president-cited-as-power-player-in-panama-papers |title=Former Sudanese President cited as 'Power Player' in Panama Papers |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 27, 2016 |work=Radio Dabanga |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602112459/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/former-sudanese-president-cited-as-power-player-in-panama-papers |archivedate=June 2, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Al-Mirghani, who was president from 1986 to 1989, created Orange Star Corporation in the British Virgin Islands through the Panama firm in 1995, when he was living in Egypt after the coup that ended his presidency. He was active in the Democratic Unionist Party there.<ref name=dabanga /> Orange Star Corporation bought a long-term lease in a tony London neighborhood near Hyde Park for $600,000 the same year al-Mirghani created it, and at the time of his death held assets worth $2.72 million.<ref name=dabanga />
==== Tunisia ==== The trial court prosecutor in Tunis ordered a judicial inquiry into the Panama Papers and Tunisian political figures suspected of hiring the firm. A judge from a Tunisian court specializing in financial crimes was assigned to the case.<ref name=realTunis>{{cite web |url=http://www.realites.com.tn/2016/04/tunisie-le-ministere-public-ouvre-une-enquete-sur-le-panama-papers/ |title=Tunisie: le ministère public ouvre une enquête sur le Panama Papers |publisher=Réalités |date=April 5, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407224018/http://www.realites.com.tn/2016/04/tunisie-le-ministere-public-ouvre-une-enquete-sur-le-panama-papers/ |archivedate=April 7, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The Tunisian [[Assembly of the Representatives of the People]] established a parliamentary commission of inquiry as well<ref>{{fr icon}} {{cite web |url=http://kapitalis.com/tunisie/2016/04/08/panama-papers-creation-dune-commission-denquete-parlementaire/ |title=Panama Papers : Création d'une commission d'enquête parlementaire |publisher=Kapitalis |date=April 8, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412150939/http://kapitalis.com/tunisie/2016/04/08/panama-papers-creation-dune-commission-denquete-parlementaire/ |archivedate=April 12, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Newspaper ''Inkyfada'' had access to the documents and reported a dozen politicians, former government officials and lawyers had been implicated, as well as a leading media figure. Monday 4 April 2016 it reported that the former secretary-general of the [[Nidaa Tounes]] political party, [[Mohsen Marzouk]], who was also the coordinator of the new political party, [[Machrouu Tounes]], was on the point of creating his own account in December 2014, in the first presidential elections. Marzouk had written Mossack Fonseca about a company in the Virgin Islands, emphasizing a desire to hold funds and conduct business overseas. Marzouk denies this and has filed a defamation complaint.<ref name=CPJinky>{{cite web |url=https://cpj.org/2016/04/news-website-inkyfada-hit-with-cyberattack-after-p.php |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529033605/https://cpj.org/2016/04/news-website-inkyfada-hit-with-cyberattack-after-p.php |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=News website Inkyfada hit with cyberattack after Panama Papers report |date=April 15, 2016 |accessdate=April 29, 2016 |author=Committee to Protect Journalists}}</ref>
''Inkyfada'' was forced to briefly shut down its website following the report due to a cyberattack that attempted to insert names of politicians who had not been mentioned in the leaked documents.<ref name=CPJinky />
==== Uganda ==== Mossack Fonseca documents provide new insight and confirmation for a previously-litigated tax case where an offshore company transferred its registration to avoid paying capital gains tax in Uganda.<ref name=Uhog /> The documents show that Heritage Oil and Gas Limited (HOGL) knew in advance of a [[capital gains tax]] that Uganda planned to enact. HOGL was then operating in Uganda and planned to sell half its Ugandan assets. It "urgently"<ref name=GuardTony /> moved its registration from the Bahamas to Mauritius to avoid the tax.<ref name=Uhog /> Mauritius has a [[double taxation]] agreement with Uganda, meaning that HOGL would pay tax in only one of the two countries.<ref name=Uhog /> But Mauritius does not have a capital gains tax, so by moving there Heritage reduced its capital gains tax to zero.<ref name=BBCug>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-35985463 |title=Panama Papers: How Jersey-based oil firm avoided taxes in Uganda |date=April 8, 2016 |publisher=BBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421072156/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-35985463 |archivedate=April 21, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Emails clearly show that this was the reason for the transfer, although company attorneys deny it.<ref name=Uhog>{{cite news |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/04/04/Panama-Papers-Leaked-emails-expose-Heritage-plot-to-dodge-Uganda-tax |title=Panama Papers: Leaked emails expose Heritage plot to dodge Uganda tax |author=Tabu Butagira |date=April 4, 2016 |accessdate=April 30, 2016 |publisher=Times Live |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420013615/http://www.timeslive.co.za/africa/2016/04/04/Panama-Papers-Leaked-emails-expose-Heritage-plot-to-dodge-Uganda-tax |archivedate=April 20, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2010, HOGL sold its 50 percent stake in Ugandan oil fields to Tullow Uganda for US$1.5 billion.<ref name=Uhog /> The [[Uganda Revenue Authority]] (URA) applied a US$404 million capital gains tax on the transaction and HOGL refused to pay.<ref name=Uhog /> A four-year battle in various courts ensued. Ugandan officials, including President [[Yoweri Museveni]] and the then-URA Commissioner-General [[Allen Kagina]] demanded the payment from Tullow, threatening not to renew its exploration licenses, which were about to expire, unless it deducted the tax from its payment to Heritage and remitted it to the URA.<ref name=Uhog /> Eventually Tullow made a down payment and deposited the rest in escrow, pending legal resolution of its appeal, which came in 2013. Tullow also successfully sued HOGL to recover taxes they had paid on its behalf.<ref name=Uhog />
Heritage Gas and Oil is a subsidiary of Heritage Oil, founded by Conservative Party donor Tony Buckingham, who has given the party more than £100,000.<ref name=GuardTony>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/04/tory-donors-links-to-offshore-firms-revealed-in-leaked-panama-papers |title=Tory donors' links to offshore firms revealed in leaked Panama Papers: Three former Conservative MPs and six peers have connections to offshore companies, despite PM's calls for reform |author=Holly Watt |date=April 4, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160730021938/https://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/04/tory-donors-links-to-offshore-firms-revealed-in-leaked-panama-papers |archivedate=July 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> As of December 31, 2008, he still owned 33.1% of Heritage Oil.<!-- last sentence is from Heritage wikipedia page -->
Uganda's ratio of tax to gross domestic product, at less than 14%, is one of the lowest in East Africa.<ref name=Uhog />
==== Zimbabwe ==== {{See also|Corruption in Zimbabwe}} [[File:Mugabecloseup2008.jpg|thumb|left|President [[Robert Mugabe|Mugabe]]]] An arms dealer and a mining tycoon with close links to President [[Robert Mugabe]] operated offshore companies despite US and European sanctions against them until 2013, more than four years after the sanctions were announced, according to the leaked documents.<ref name=GMafrica />
According to the Panama Papers, [[Platinum in Africa#Zimbabwe|Zimplats Holdings]], a large platinum mining concern, set up a shell company to pay the salaries of its senior managers. Zimplats denies knowledge of the company, HR Consultancy.<ref name=ANCIRhr>{{cite news |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/zimbabwe/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529033522/https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/zimbabwe/ |archivedate=2016-05-29 |title=Zimplats denies knowledge of offshore accounts |author1=Ray Choto |author2=ANCIR |work=#Panama Papers: How the elite hide their wealth |accessdate=April 30, 2016}}</ref> The company, which was still active in 2015, was unknown to the [[Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe]],<ref name=ANCIRhr /> which may indicate externalization of funds and tax evasion if, as it appears, the salaries were for citizens of Zimbabwe performing work in Zimbabwe.<ref name=ANCIRhr /> {{clearleft}}
=== Oceania ===
==== Australia ==== On April 22, 2016, Australia said it would create a public register showing the beneficial, or actual, owners of shell companies, as part of an effort to stamp out tax avoidance by multinational corporations.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/australasia/article/1937728/australia-create-public-register-shell-company-owners-wake |title=Australia to create public register of shell company owners, in wake of Panama Papers |publisher=South China Morning Post |date=April 22, 2016 |accessdate=April 22, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423193649/http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/australasia/article/1937728/australia-create-public-register-shell-company-owners-wake |archivedate=April 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
