{{about|student-related bullying at school|teacher-related bullying at school|Bullying in teaching}} {{Inadequate lead|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} [[File:Bullying on Instituto Regional Federico Errázuriz (IRFE) in March 5, 2007.jpg|thumb|Bullying, one form of which is depicted in this staged photograph, is detrimental to students' well-being and development.<ref name="nces-2005-310">{{cite report |url=http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2005/2005310.pdf |title=Student Reports of Bullying: Results From the 2001 School Crime Supplement to the National Crime Victimization Survey |author=U.S. National Center for Education Statistics}}</ref>]] '''School bullying''' is a type of [[bullying]] that occurs in any [[learning space|educational setting]].
For an act to be considered bullying it must meet certain criteria. This includes hostile intent, imbalance of power, repetition, distress, and provocation. Bullying can have a wide spectrum of effects on a student including anger, depression, stress and suicide. Additionally, the bully can develop different social disorders or have a higher chance of engaging in criminal activity.
If there is suspicion that a child is being bullied or is a bully, there are warning signs in their behavior. There are many programs and organizations worldwide which provide bullying prevention services or information on how children can cope if they have been bullied.
== Definition == There is no universal definition of school bullying; however, it is widely agreed that bullying is a subcategory of [[aggressive behavior]] characterized by the following three minimum criteria:<ref name="Burger 2015">{{cite journal |last=Burger |first=Christoph |last2=Strohmeier |first2=Dagmar |last3=Spröber |first3=Nina |last4=Bauman |first4=Sheri |last5=Rigby |first5=Ken |date=2015 |title=How teachers respond to school bullying: An examination of self-reported intervention strategy use, moderator effects, and concurrent use of multiple strategies |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Sheri_Bauman/publication/282641314_How_teachers_respond_to_school_bullying_An_examination_of_self-reported_intervention_strategy_use_moderator_effects_and_concurrent_use_of_multiple_strategies/links/56277c7808aefb81befbab5d.pdf |journal=Teaching and Teacher Education |volume=51 |pages=191–202 |doi=10.1016/j.tate.2015.07.004}}</ref> *hostile intent (i.e., the harm caused by bullying is deliberate, not accidental),<ref name="Goldsmid_and_Howie">{{cite journal |last1=Goldsmid |first1=S. |last2=Howie |first2=P. |year=2014 |title=Bullying by definition: An examination of definitional components of bullying |url= |journal=Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=210–225 |doi=10.1080/13632752.2013.844414}} {{closed access}}</ref> *imbalance of power (i.e., bullying includes a real or perceived power inequity between the bully and the victim),<ref name="Goldsmid_and_Howie"/> and *repetition over a period of time (i.e., more than once with the potential to occur multiple times).<ref name="Goldsmid_and_Howie"/>
The following two additional criteria have been proposed to complement the above-mentioned criteria: * victim distress (victim suffers mild to severe psychological, social or physical trauma)<ref name="Goldsmid_and_Howie"/> and * provocation (bullying is motivated by perceived benefits of their aggressive behaviors).<ref name="Goldsmid_and_Howie"/>
Some of these characteristics have been disputed (e.g., for power imbalance: bullies and victims often report that conflicts occur between two equals); nevertheless, they remain widely established in the scientific literature.<ref name="Burger 2015"/>
== Underlying causes == The underlying causes of school violence and bullying include gender and social norms and wider contextual and structural factors.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002469/246970e.pdf |title=School Violence and Bullying: Global Status Report |last=UNESCO |first= |publisher=Paris, UNESCO |year=2017 |isbn=978-92-3-100197-0 |location= |pages=17, 29, 31}}</ref>
Discriminatory [[Gender role|gender norms]] that shape the dominance of men and the subservience of women and the perpetuation of these norms through violence are found in some form in many cultures. [[Gender inequality]] and the prevalence of [[violence against women]] in society exacerbate the problem. Similarly, social norms that support the authority of teachers over children may legitimise the use of violence to maintain discipline and control.<ref name=":02" />
The pressure to conform to dominant gender norms is also high.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Meyer |first=Doug |date= |title=The Disregarding of Heteronormativity: Emphasizing a Happy Queer Adulthood and Localizing Anti-Queer Violence to Adolescent Schools |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s13178-016-0272-7 |journal=Sexuality Research & Social Policy |volume=14 |issue=3 |page=331 |via= |doi=10.1007/s13178-016-0272-7 |year=2017}}</ref> Young people who cannot or who choose not to conform to these norms are often punished for this through violence and bullying at school.<ref name=":02" />
Schools themselves can "teach" children to be violent through discriminatory practices, curricula and textbooks. If unchecked, gender discrimination and power imbalances in schools can encourage attitudes and practices that subjugate children, uphold unequal gender norms and tolerate violence, including corporal punishment.<ref name=":02" />
Some attribute part of the cause of bullying to the [[Bullying culture|atmosphere]] in which it occurs. Thornberg and Knutsen state in their study, "School attributing refers to attributing the cause of bullying to the school setting." They say that school attributing has two subcategories which are "boredom in school" and "poor antibullying practices". Boredom in school involves a student who does not have anything else to do other than bully. Poor antibullying practices may include teachers and staff not caring enough to intervene, or a school not having enough teachers for students. This may lead to the students feeling unwanted or unimportant due to the lack of care from the school's staff.<ref> {{cite journal |author=Thornberg, Robert, and Sven Knutsen |title=Teenagers' Explanations of Bullying |journal=Child & Youth Care Forum |volume=40 |issue=3 |page=177 |doi=10.1007/s10566-010-9129-z |year=2010}}</ref>
Schools and the education system also operate within the context of wider social and structural factors and may reflect and reproduce environments that do not protect children and adolescents from violence and bullying. For example, physical and sexual violence may be more prevalent in schools in contexts where it is also more prevalent in wider society. Studies suggest that sexual violence and harassment of girls is worse in schools where other forms of violence are prevalent, and in conflict and emergency contexts,<ref>[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002321/232107E.pdf School-related gender-based violence is preventing the achievement of quality education for all]. UNESCO Policy Paper 17 (March 2015)</ref> and that [[Gang|gang violence]] is more common in schools where gangs, weapons and drugs are part of the local culture.<ref name=":02" />
In their paper "Predicting Bullying: Exploring the Contributions of Childhood Negative Life Experiences in Predicting Adolescent Bullying Behavior," Connell, Morris and Piquero identify three primary aspects of a child's life- family, school and peers- as major indicators to whether or not that child exhibits behavior akin to bullying.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Connell |first=Nadine M. |last2=Morris |first2=Robert G. |last3=Piquero |first3=Alex R. |date=July 2016 |title=Predicting Bullying: Exploring the Contributions of Childhood Negative Life Experiences in Predicting Adolescent Bullying Behavior |journal=International Journal of Offender Therapy and Comparative Criminology |volume=60 |issue=9 |pages=1082–1096 |doi=10.1177/0306624X15573760 |issn=1552-6933 |pmid=25759430}}</ref>
== Prevention == Bullying can threaten students' physical and emotional safety at school and can negatively impact their ability to learn. The best way to address bullying is to stop it before it starts. There are many different groups that can intervene to address bullying (and cyberbullying) in schools: parents, teachers, and school leadership.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Morgan |first=H |title=Malicious Use of Technology: What Schools, Parents, and Teachers Can Do to Prevent Cyberbullying |url=https://doi.org/10.1080/00094056.2013.792636 |journal=Childhood Education |volume=89 |pages=146–151 |via=Taylor & Francis}}</ref> The most commonly used strategies by teachers to prevent it are to communicate, mediate and seek help.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Giménez-Gualdo |first=Ana-M. |last2=Arnaiz-Sánchez |first2=Pilar |last3=Cerezo-Ramírez |first3=Fuensanta |last4=Prodócimo |first4=Elaine |date=2018-07-01 |title=Teachers' and students' perception about cyberbullying. Intervention and coping strategies in primary and secondary education |url=https://doi.org/10.3916/C56-2018-03 |journal=Comunicar |language=es |volume=26 |issue=56 |doi=10.3916/c56-2018-03 |issn=1134-3478}}</ref> Training school staff and students to prevent and address bullying can help sustain bullying prevention efforts over time. There are no federal mandates for bullying curricula or staff training. In addition to addressing bullying before it occurs, a great prevention strategy is to educate the students on bullying.<ref name="US Govt"/>
Examples of activities to teach about bullying include:
* Internet or library research, such as looking up types of bullying, how to prevent it, and how kids should respond * Presentations, such as a speech or role-play on stopping bullying * Discussions about topics like reporting bullying * Creative writing, such as a poem speaking out against bullying or a story or skit teaching bystanders how to help * Artistic works, such as a collage about respect or the effects of bullying * Classroom meetings to talk about peer relations<ref name="US Govt">{{Cite news |url=https://www.stopbullying.gov/prevention/at-school/index.html |title=Prevention at School |date=2012-02-29 |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|access-date=2018-04-26}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
== Effects == A victim, in the short term, may feel [[Depression (mood)|depressed]], anxious, angry, have [[Stress (psychological)|excessive stress]], [[learned helplessness]], feel as though their life has fallen apart, have a significant drop in school performance, or may commit [[suicide]] ([[bullycide]]). In the long term, they may feel [[Emotional security|insecure]], lack [[trust (social sciences)|trust]], exhibit extreme sensitivity ([[hypervigilance|hypervigilant]]), or develop a mental illness such as [[psychopathy]], [[avoidant personality disorder]] or [[PTSD]]. They may also desire [[Revenge|vengeance]], sometimes leading them to torment others in return.<ref>{{cite web |author=Dombeck, Mark |title=The Long Term Effects of Bullying |url=https://www.mentalhelp.net/articles/the-long-term-effects-of-bullying/}}</ref>
Anxiety, depression and psychosomatic symptoms are common among both bullies and their victims. Among these participants alcohol and substance abuse are commonly seen later in life.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=KALTIALA HEINO |first=RIITTAKERTTU |last2=RIMPELÄ |first2=MATTI |last3=RANTANEN |first3=PÄIVI |last4=RIMPELÄ |first4=ARJA |date=1 December 2000 |title=Bullying at school—an indicator of adolescents at risk for mental disorders |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140197100903518 |journal=Journal of Adolescence |volume=23 |issue=6 |pages=661–674 |doi=10.1006/jado.2000.0351}}</ref> It is known that people suffering from depression feel much better when they talk to others about it, but victims of bullying fear may not talk to others about their feelings in fear of being bullied, which can worsen their depression.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Olweus |first1=D |title=Bullying at school |date=1993 |publisher=Malden, MA |accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
In the short term, being a bystander "can produce feelings of anger, fear, guilt, and sadness.... Bystanders who witness repeated victimizations of peers can experience negative effects similar to the victimized children themselves."<ref name="Hirsch, L. 2012" />
While most bullies, in the long term, grow up to be emotionally functional adults, many have an increased risk of developing [[antisocial personality disorder]], which is linked to an increased risk of committing criminal acts (including [[domestic violence]]).<ref>{{cite web |title=Long-Term Effects Of Bullying: Pain Lasts Into Adulthood (STUDY) |work=Huffington Post |accessdate=15 April 2014 |date=20 February 2013 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/20/long-term-effects-of-bullying_n_2728190.html |author=Pappas, Stephanie}}</ref>
=== Negative impact on educational quality and outcomes === The educational effects on victims of school violence and bullying are significant. Violence and bullying at the hands of teachers or other students may make children and adolescents afraid to go to school and interfere with their ability to concentrate in class or participate in school activities. It can also have similar effects on bystanders.<ref name=":02" />
The consequences include missing classes, avoiding school activities, playing truant or dropping out of school altogether. This in turn has an adverse impact on academic achievement and attainment and on future education and employment prospects. Children and adolescents who are victims of violence may achieve lower grades and may be less likely to anticipate going on to higher education. Analyses of international learning assessments highlight the impact of bullying on learning outcomes. These analyses clearly show that bullying reduces students' achievement in key subjects, such as mathematics, and other studies have documented the negative impact of school violence and bullying on educational performance.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=24298004 |year=2014 |author1=Devries |first1=K. M |title=School violence, mental health, and educational performance in Uganda |journal=Pediatrics |volume=133 |issue=1 |pages=e129–37 |last2=Child |first2=J. C |last3=Allen |first3=E |last4=Walakira |first4=E |last5=Parkes |first5=J |last6=Naker |first6=D |doi=10.1542/peds.2013-2007}}</ref><ref name=":02" />
Bystanders and the school climate as a whole are also affected by school violence and bullying. Unsafe learning environments create a climate of fear and insecurity and a perception that teachers do not have control or do not care about the students, and this reduces the quality of education for all.<ref name=":02" />
=== Social and economic costs === The 2006 UN World Report on Violence against Children shows that victims of corporal punishment, both at school and at home, may develop into adults who are passive and over-cautious or aggressive. Involvement in school bullying can be a predictor of future antisocial and criminal behaviour. Being bullied is also linked to a heightened risk of eating disorders and social and relationship difficulties.<ref>UNICEF (2014). [https://www.unicef.org/publications/index_74865.html Hidden in plain sight: A statistical analysis of violence against children]. {{ISBN|978-92-806-4767-9}}.</ref><ref name=":02" />
Other studies have shown the longer-term effects of bullying at school. One study of all children born in England, Scotland and Wales during one week in 1958 analyzes data on 7,771 children who had been bullied at ages 7 and 11. At age 50, those who had been bullied as children were less likely to have obtained school qualifications and less likely to live with a spouse or partner or to have adequate social support. They also had lower scores on word memory tests designed to measure cognitive IQ even when their childhood intelligence levels were taken into account and, more often reported, that they had poor health. The effects of bullying were visible nearly four decades later, with health, social and economic consequences lasting well into adulthood. For children, "peers are a much more important influence than has been realised. It is a terrible thing to be excluded by your peers".<ref>Smith, Rebecca (18 April 2014). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/children/10772302/Bullying-at-school-affects-health-40-years-later.html Bullying at school affects health 40 years later]. Telegraph. Retrieved on 2017-10-28.</ref><ref name=":02" />
The economic impact of violence against children and adolescents is substantial.<ref>WHO (2016). Inspire. Seven strategies for ending violence against children.</ref> Youth violence in Brazil alone is estimated to cost nearly US$19 billion every year, of which US$943 million can be linked to violence in schools. The estimated cost to the economy in the USA of violence associated with schools is US$7.9 billion a year.<ref>Special Representative of the Secretary-General on Violence against Children (2012). Tackling violence in schools: A global perspective bridging the gap between standards and practice.</ref><ref name=":02" />
Analytic work supported by the [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID) shows that school-related gender-based violence alone can be associated with the loss of one primary grade of schooling, which translates to an annual cost of around US$17 billion to low- and middle-income countries.<ref>RTI International. (2015). [http://www.ungei.org/resources/6089.htm What is the cost of school-related gender-based violence?] USAID.</ref><ref name=":02" />
In the East Asia and Pacific region, it is estimated that the economic costs of just some of the health consequences of child maltreatment were equivalent to between 1.4% and 2.5% of the region's annual GDP.<ref name=":02" />
In Argentina, the forgone benefit to society from overall early school dropout is 11.4% of GDP, and in Egypt, nearly 7% of potential earnings is lost as a result of the number of children dropping out of school.<ref name=":02" />
A study has shown that each year Cameroon, Democratic Republic of Congo and Nigeria lose US$974 million, US$301 million and US$1,662 million respectively for failing to educate girls to the same standard as boys, and violence in school is one of the key factors contributing to the under-representation of girls in education.<ref>Plan (2008). [https://www.unicef.org/wcaro/documents_publications_4271.html Paying the Price, cited in Antonowicz, Laetitia, Too Often in Silence. A report on school-based violence in West and Central Africa].</ref><ref name=":02" />
== Statistics == According to the [[American Psychological Association]], "40% to 80% of school-age children experience bullying at some point during their school careers."<ref name="apa.org">{{cite web |last=Graham |first=Sandra |title=Bullying: A Module for Teachers |work=American Psychological Association |accessdate=30 December 2012 |url=http://www.apa.org/education/k12/bullying.aspx}}</ref> Various studies show that students from [[Socioeconomic status|lower socioeconomic backgrounds]] experience bullying more often than other students.<ref name="victimization">{{Cite journal |last1=Agirdag |first1=O. |last2=Demanet |first2=J. |last3=Van Houtte |first3=M. |last4=Van Avermaet |first4=P. |last5=Bettelheim |first5=K. A. |title=Ethnic school composition and peer victimization: A focus on the interethnic school climate |doi=10.1016/j.ijintrel.2010.09.009 |journal=International Journal of Intercultural Relations |volume=35 |issue=4 |year=2011 |pages=465–473 |url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/38493480/Victimization_-_IJIR.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAJ56TQJRTWSMTNPEA&Expires=1474238954&Signature=VX2YP9sNdpIK%2BiaVffH7BzAuFms%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DEthnic_school_composition_and_peer_victi.pdf}} {{dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref> The following statistics help illustrate the severity of bullying within classrooms:<ref name="apa.org" />
=== Victims === *Statistics show that 1 in 3 children are affected by bullying in their lifetime in the U.S. school system, and 30% report being involved in some manner.<ref name="Sign In">{{cite web |url=http://cs.oxfordjournals.org/content/27/2/101.full.pdf+html |title=Sign In |website=cs.oxfordjournals.org|access-date=26 October 2016}}</ref> *A nationwide survey of bullying in first and second level schools conducted by Trinity College Dublin estimates that some 31% of primary and 16% of secondary students have been bullied at some time.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Nationwide Study on Bullying Behaviour in Irish Schools (O'Moore 1997), Anti Bullying Centre, Trinity College Dublin. |url=http://bully4u.ie/bullying-in-schools/understanding/statistics-on-bullying-in-irish-schools/ |journal= |volume=|access-date=15 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161116015231/http://bully4u.ie/bullying-in-schools/understanding/statistics-on-bullying-in-irish-schools/|archive-date=16 November 2016|dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all}}</ref> *In a 1997 study of five [[Seattle]] high schools, students recorded their peers' hallway and classroom conversations. It was discovered that the average high school student hears about 25 anti-gay remarks a day.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cook |first1=Hilary |title=LLB}}</ref> * In a study conducted across 32 Dutch elementary schools, 16.2% of the 2,766 participating children reported being bullied regularly (at least several times a month).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fekkes |first1=M. |last2=Pijpers |first2=F. I. M. |last3=Verloove-Vanhorick |first3=S. P. |year=2005 |title=Bullying: Who does what, when and where? involvement of children, teachers and parents in bullying behavior |pmid=15253993}}</ref> * At least 1 in 3 adolescent students in Canada has reported being bullied.<ref name="cihr-irsc.gc.ca">{{cite web |url=http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/45838.html |title=Canadian Statistics referencing the prevalence of bullying in schools may be inaccurate and tend to fluctuate. In a U.S. study of 5,621 students ages 12–18, 64% of the students had experienced bullying and did not report it.<ref>{{cite report |author=Petrosino, A., Guckenburg, S., DeVoe, J., and Hanson, T. |date=2010 |title=What characteristics of bullying, bullying victims, and schools are associated with increased reporting of bullying to school officials? |work=Issues & Answers Report |number=092 |publisher=Regional Educational Laboratory Northeast and Islands |url=http://ies.ed.gov/ncee/edlabs/regions/northeast/pdf/REL_2010092.pdf}}</ref>
=== Bullies === Proactive aggression is a behavior that expects a reward. With bullying each individual has a role to defend.{{clarify|date=October 2016}} Some children act proactively but will show aggression to defend themselves if provoked. These children will react aggressively but tend to never be the ones to attack first.
There have been two subtypes created in bully classification; popular aggressive and unpopular aggressive. Popular aggressive bullies are social and do not encounter a great deal of social stigma from their aggression. Unpopular aggressive bullies, however, are most often rejected by other students and use aggression to seek attention.<ref name="Sign In"/> * In a recent national survey 3,708,284 students reported being a perpetrator of bullying in the U.S. school system.<ref name="Sign In"/> * Studies have shown bullies actually report more success in making friends than other children. * Bullying behavior in perpatrators is shown to decrease with age.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dake |first=Joseph A. |last2=Price |first2=James H. |last3=Telljohann |first3=Susan K. |date=1 May 2003 |title=The Nature and Extent of Bullying at School |journal=Journal of School Health |volume=73 |issue=5 |pages=173–180 |doi=10.1111/j.1746-1561.2003.tb03599.x |pmid=12793102}}</ref> * Developmental research suggests bullies are often morally disengaged and use [[egocentric]] reasoning strategies.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Perren |first1=S. |last2=Gutzwiller-Helfenfinger |first2=E. |last3=Malti |first3=T. |last4=Hymel |first4=S. |year=2012 |title=Moral Reasoning and Emotion Attributions of Adolescent Bullies, Victims, and Bully-Victims |url=https://kops.uni-konstanz.de/bitstream/handle/123456789/21618/Perren_216187.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y |journal=British Journal of Developmental Psychology |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=511–530 |doi=10.1111/j.2044-835x.2011.02059.x |pmid=23039330}}</ref> *Adolescents who experience violence or aggression in the home, or are influenced by negative peer relationships, are more likely to bully. This suggests that positive social relationships reduce the likelihood of bullying.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Keelan |first1=C. |last2=Schenk |first2=A. |last3=McNally |first3=M. |last4=Fremouw |first4=W. |year=2014 |title=The interpersonal worlds of bullies: Parents, peers, and partners |url= |journal=Journal of Interpersonal Violence |volume=29 |issue=7 |pages=1338–1353 |doi=10.1177/0886260513506278}} {{closed access}}</ref> *The diagnosis of a [[mental health disorder]] is strongly associated with being a bully. This trend is most evident in adolescents diagnosed with [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], [[Anxiety disorder|anxiety]], or [[ADHD]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0886260514536279 |last1=Benedict |first1=Frances Turcotte |last2=Vivier |first2=Patrick M. |last3=Gjelsvik |first3=Annie |title=Mental Health and Bullying in the United States Among Children Aged 6 to 17 Years |journal=Journal of Interpersonal Violence |year=2014 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Frances_Benedict/publication/263097736_Mental_Health_and_Bullying_in_the_United_States_Among_Children_Aged_6_to_17_Years/links/540902270cf2822fb738bccd.pdf |pmid=24920001 |volume=30 |issue=5 |pages=782–95}}</ref> * Poor [[theory of mind]] is associated with bullying.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shakoor |first1=S. |last2=Jaffee |first2=S. R. |last3=Bowes |first3=L. |last4=Ouellet-Morin |first4=I. |last5=Andreou |first5=P. |last6=Happé |first6=F. |last7=Arseneault |first7=L. |year=2012 |title=A prospective longitudinal study of children's theory of mind and adolescent involvement in bullying |url= |journal=Journal of Child Psychology & Psychiatry |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=254–261 |doi=10.1111/j.1469-7610.2011.02488.x |pmc=3272094 |pmid=22081896}}</ref> * 25% of students encourage bullying if not given proper education and information about the consequences of bullying.<ref name="greatschools.org">{{cite web |last=Wilde |first=Marian |title=The bully and the bystander |work=GreatSchools |accessdate=30 December 2012 |url=http://www.greatschools.org/gk/articles/the-bully-and-the-bystander/}}</ref> * A study by Lisa Garby shows that 60% of bullies in middle school will have at least one criminal conviction by the age of 24.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Garby |first=Lisa |title=Direct Bullying: Criminal Act or Mimicking What Has Been Learned? |journal=Education |year=2011 |volume=20 |issue=1 |page=449}}</ref>
In a survey by the [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] (NICHD), students were asked to complete a questionnaire.
<blockquote>A total of 10.6% of the children replied that they had sometimes bullied other children, a response category defined as moderate bullying. An additional 8.8% said they had bullied others once a week or more, defined as frequent bullying. Similarly, 8.5% said they had been targets of moderate bullying, and 8.4% said they were bullied frequently. Out of all the students, 13% said they had engaged in moderate or frequent bullying of others, while 10.6% said they had been bullied either moderately or frequently. Some students — 6.3% — had both bullied others and been bullied themselves. In all, 29% of the students who responded to the survey had been involved in some aspect of bullying, either as a bully, as the target of bullying or both.<ref>{{cite web |last=NIH |title=Bullying Widespread in U.S. Schools, Survey Finds |work=NICHD Archive |date=26 June 2006 |url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/news/releases/pages/bullying.aspx}}</ref></blockquote>
According to Tara Kuther, an associate professor of psychology at [[Western Connecticut State University]], "...bullying gets so much more sophisticated and subtle in high school. It's more [[relational aggression|relational]]. It becomes more difficult for teens to know when to intervene; whereas with younger kids, bullying is more physical and, therefore, more clear-cut."<ref name="greatschools.org" />
== Types of bullying == There are four basic types of bullying: verbal, physical, psychological, and cyber. Cyberbullying is becoming one of the most common types. While victims can experience bullying at any age, it is witnessed most often in school-aged children.
Direct bullying is a relatively open attack on a victim that is physical and/or verbal in nature.<ref name="Hirsch, L. 2012">{{cite book |publisher=Weinstein Books |isbn=978-1-60286-184-8 |oclc=792879631 |last1=Hirsch |first1=Lee |last2=Lowen |first2=Cynthia |last3=Santorelli |first3=Dina |title=Bully: An action plan for teachers and parents to combat the bullying crisis |location=New York |date=2012}}</ref> Indirect bullying is more subtle and harder to detect, but involves one or more forms of relational aggression, including [[Isolation to facilitate abuse|social isolation]] via intentional exclusion, spreading rumors to defame one's character or reputation, making faces or obscene gestures behind someone's back, and manipulating friendships or other relationships.<ref name="Hirsch, L. 2012" />
Pack bullying is bullying undertaken by a group. The 2009 Wesley Report on bullying found that pack bullying was more prominent in high schools and lasted longer than bullying undertaken by individuals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Facts About School Bullies and Bullying Behaviors |work=Bullying Statistics |url=http://www.bullyingstatistics.org/content/school-bullying.html}}</ref>
=== Physical === {{See also|Physical abuse}} [[File:Rebecca1917version.jpg|250px|thumb|A female bully, portrayed in the 1917 silent film ''[[Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm (1917 film)|Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm]]'']] Physical bullying is any unwanted physical contact between the bully and the victim. This is one of the most easily identifiable forms of bullying. Examples include:<ref name="stopbullyingnow.hrsa.gov">{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220222902/http://stopbullyingnow.hrsa.gov/index.asp?area=whatbullyingis | archive-date=20 February 2009 |url=http://stopbullyingnow.hrsa.gov/index.asp?area=whatbullyingis |title=So what is bullying? |work=Stop Bullying Now!}}</ref><ref name="Bolton">{{cite book |publisher=Boys Town Press |isbn=978-1-889322-67-4 |author1=Bolton, José |author2=Graeve, Stan |title=No room for bullies: from the classroom to cyberspace |location=Nebraska |date=2005}}</ref>
{{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * fighting * [[hazing]] * [[headlock]]s * inappropriate touching * kicking * pinching * poking * [[List of school pranks|pranking]] * pulling hair * punching * pushing * shoving * [[teasing]] * threatening * [[tickling]] * using weapons, including improvised ones }}
=== Emotional === {{See also|Psychological abuse}} Emotional bullying is any form of bullying that causes damage to a victim's [[Psyche (psychology)|psyche]] and/or [[emotional well-being]]. Examples include:<ref name="stopbullyingnow.hrsa.gov" /><ref name="Bolton" />
* Spreading malicious [[rumor]]s about people * Getting certain people to "gang up" on others (this could also be considered physical bullying) * Ignoring people on purpose (via the [[silent treatment]] or pretending the victim is non-existent) * Provoking others * Belittling, making fun of people, or saying hurtful things (which are also forms of verbal bullying)<ref name=belittling>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccpa-accp.ca/blog/?p=3021 |title=The Effects of Belittling |publisher=Counselling Connect |accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref>
=== Verbal === {{See also|Verbal abuse}} Verbal bullying is any slanderous statements or accusations that cause the victim undue emotional distress. Examples include:<ref name="Bolton" />
* Directing foul language ([[profanity]]) at the target * Using [[derogatory]] terms or deriding the person's name * Commenting negatively on someone's looks, clothes, body, etc. ([[personal abuse]]) * [[Suffering|Tormenting]] * [[harassment|Harassing]] * Mocking and belittling<ref name="belittling" /> *Threatening to cause harm<ref name="stopbullying.gov">stopbullying.gov</ref> *Taunting<ref name="stopbullying.gov"/> *Teasing<ref name="stopbullying.gov"/> *Inappropriate sexual comments<ref name="stopbullying.gov"/>
=== Cyberbullying === Cyberbullying is the quickest growing form of harassment of school campuses in the U.S. and 40% of adolescent report being a victim.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hvidston |first=David |date= |title=Cyberbullying: Implications for Principal Leadership |url=https://doi.org/10.1177/0192636513504452 |journal=NASSP Bulletin |volume=97 |pages=297–313 |via=Sage Journals}}</ref> Most definitions of cyberbullying come from definitions of school bullying. Thus, this conduct is often described as an intentional aggressive behavior that takes place via new technologies, during which groups or individuals hurt classmates who cannot easily defend themselves. Cyberbullying events can occur via cellphones or computers, by means of text messages, e-mails, online social networks, chatrooms or blogs.<ref name="sciencedirect.com">{{Cite journal |date=2015-02-01 |title=Does cyberbullying overlap with school bullying when taking modality of involvement into account? |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S074756321400572X |journal=Computers in Human Behavior |volume=43 |pages=49–57 |doi=10.1016/j.chb.2014.10.049 |issn=0747-5632}}</ref> This form of bullying can easily go undetected because of the lack of parental or authoritative supervision. Because bullies can pose as someone else, it is the most anonymous form of bullying. Like the bullying that occurs in school, the following four profiles have been identified: cyberneutral, cyberbully, cybervictim and cyberbully-victim.<ref name="sciencedirect.com"/> Many who are bullied in school are likely to be bullied over the Internet and vice versa.<ref name="Bolton" /> Since students have become more reliant on internet, the advancement in social media and technology has altered the fear of in-person bullying away from schoolyards but has rather increase cyberbullying.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kowalski, R. M., Limber, S. & Agatston, P. W. |title=Cyberbullying: bullying in the digital age |date=2012 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |location=Malden, M.A |isbn= |edition=2nd |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> Studies have shown almost half of cyberbullies are repeat offenders and harass others as few at three times.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Li |first=Qing |date=1 May 2006 |title=Cyberbullying in Schools A Research of Gender Differences |journal=School Psychology International |volume=27 |issue=2 |pages=157–170 |doi=10.1177/0143034306064547}}</ref> Males are more likely to be active cyberbullies than females. Cyberbullying can happen 24 hours a day and seven days a week and reach a child even when they are alone. Deleting inappropriate or harassing messages, texts or pictures is extremely difficult after being posted or sent.<ref>stopbullying.com</ref>
==== Prevention ==== According to the website Stop Cyberbullying, "When schools try and get involved by disciplining the student for cyberbullying actions that took place off campus and outside of school hours, they are often sued for exceeding their authority and violating the student's free speech right." <ref name="Stop Cyberbullying">{{cite web |title=What is cyberbullying, exactly? |url=http://stopcyberbullying.org/what_is_cyberbullying_exactly.html |publisher=Stop cyberbullying |accessdate=29 October 2013}}</ref> They suggest for schools to make revisions to their policies that would allow for disciplinary actions to take place even if off campus or after hours. They say if the act is likely to affect a student mentally or physically while in school then the revision of the policy would allow for the staff to intervene without violating the student's constitutional rights. Many principals are hesitant to act because school discipline codes and states laws do not define cyberbullying. According to professor Bernard James, "educators are empowered to maintain safe schools, the timidity of educators in this context of emerging technology is working in advantage of the bullies."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/28/style/28bully.html |title=How Should Schools Handle Cyberbullying? |last=Hoffman |first=Jan |date=2010-06-27 |work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-20 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Cyberbullying has become extremely prevalent; 95% of teens who use [[social media]] reported having witnessed malicious behavior on social media from 2009 to 2013.<ref>{{cite web |last=Boschert |first=Sherry |title=Cyberbullying triples suicide risk in teens |work=Pediatric News |url=http://www.pediatricnews.com/specialty-focus/mental-health/single-article-page/cyberbullying-triples-suicide-risk-in-teens.html}}</ref> As sites like [[Facebook]] or [[Twitter]] offer no routine monitoring, children from a young age must learn proper internet behavior, say Abraham Foxman and Cyndi Silverman. "This is a call for parents and educators to teach these modern skills... through awareness and advocacy."<ref>{{cite web |title=Social Networking Sites Can Be Forums for Cyberbullying |work=Opposing Viewpoints in Context |url=http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/ovic/ViewpointsDetailsPage/DocumentToolsPortletWindow?displayGroupName=Viewpoints&jsid=338bbf8461b0eccf737c3bc28daee63f&action=2&catId=&documentId=GALE%7CEJ3010744205&u=plan_smcol&zid=9df104e26321ef3abe1a4c867b490850}}</ref> Per Scott Eidler, "Parents and educators need to make children aware at a young age of the life-changing effects cyberbullying can have on the victim. The next step for prevention is advocacy. For example, three high school students from [[Melville, New York]] organized a Bullying Awareness Walk, where several hundred people turned out to show their support."<ref>{{cite web |last=Eidler |first=Scott |title=Anti-bullying walk held in North Hempstead |work=Newsday |accessdate=21 September 2013 |date=6 March 2013 |url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/anti-bullying-walk-held-in-north-hempstead-1.5022005}}</ref>
Clara Wajngurt writes, "Other than organizing events, calling for social media sites to take charge could make the difference between life and death. Cyberbullying is making it increasingly difficult to enforce any form of prevention."<ref name="wajngurt">{{cite web |last=Wajngurt |first=Clara |title=Anti-Bullying Policies in Higher Ed |url=http://www.niot.org/node/7125 |publisher=Not in Our Town |accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> Joanna Wojcik concludes, "The rapid growth of social media is aiding the spread of cyberbullying, and prevention policies are struggling to keep up. In order for prevention policies to be put in place, the definition of cyberbullying must be stated, others must be educated on how to recognize and prevent bullying, and policies that have already attempted to be enacted need to be reviewed and learned from."<ref>{{cite web |last=Wojcik |first=Joanne |title=Cyber bullying cases test schools' legal reach |work=Business Insurance |date=4 March 2012 |url=http://www.businessinsurance.com/article/20120304/NEWS05/303049991}} </ref>
Researcher Charisse Nixon found that students do not reach out for help with cyberbullying for four main reasons: they do not feel connected to the adults around them; the students do not see the cyberbullying as an issue that is worth bringing forward; they do not feel the surrounding adults have the ability to properly deal with the cyberbullying; and the teenagers have increased feelings of shame and humiliation regarding the cyberbullying.<ref name="Adolescent Health 2014">{{cite journal |doi=10.2147/AHMT.S36456 |volume=5 |pages=143–158 |last=Nixon |first=Charisse L |title=Current perspectives: the impact of cyberbullying on adolescent health |journal=Adolescent Health, Medicine and Therapeutics |date=1 July 2014 |pmid=25177157 |pmc=4126576}}</ref> Nixon also found that when bystanders took action in helping end the cyberbullying in adolescents, the results were more positive than when the adolescents attempted to resolve the situation without outside help.<ref name="Adolescent Health 2014"/>
=== Sexual bullying === {{Main|Sexual bullying}} Sexual bullying is "any bullying behavior, whether physical or non-physical, that is based on a person's sexuality or gender. It is when sexuality or gender is used as a weapon by boys or girls towards other boys or girls—although it is more commonly directed at girls. It can be carried out to a person's face, behind their back or [[Cyber-bullying|through the use of technology]]."<ref name="NSPCC02">{{cite web |url=http://www.nspcc.org.uk/Inform/resourcesforteachers/classroomresources/sexual_bullying_definition_wdf68769.pdf |title=NSPCC working definition of Sexual Bullying |publisher=[[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children|NSPCC]] |accessdate=22 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613025646/http://www.nspcc.org.uk/Inform/resourcesforteachers/classroomresources/sexual_bullying_definition_wdf68769.pdf | archive-date=13 June 2010}}</ref>
As part of its research into sexual bullying in schools, the [[BBC]] TV series ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' commissioned a questionnaire aimed at people aged 11 to 19 in schools and youth clubs across five regions of [[England]].<ref name="BBC01">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/panorama/hi/front_page/newsid_7811000/7811468.stm |title=Rising problem of sexual bullying in schools |publisher=BBC [[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]] |date=5 January 2009 |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> The survey revealed that of the 273 respondents, 28 had been forced to do something sexual, and 31 had seen it happen to someone else. Of the 273 respondents, 40 had experienced unwanted touching.<ref name="NSPCC01">{{cite web |url=http://www.nspcc.org.uk/Inform/research/questions/sexual_bullying_wda70106.html |title=What is sexual bullying, and how can I manage it within educational settings? |publisher=NSPCC |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> U.K. government figures show that in the 2007–2008 school year, there were 3,450 fixed-period exclusions and 120 expulsions from schools in England due to sexual misconduct.<ref name="DCSF01">{{cite web |url=http://www.dcsf.gov.uk/rsgateway/DB/SFR/s000860/index.shtml |title=Permanent and Fixed Period Exclusions from Schools in England 2007/08 |publisher=UK Government's [[Department for Children, Schools and Families]] |date=30 July 2009 |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> This included incidents such as [[groping]] and using sexually insulting language. From April 2008 to March 2009, [[ChildLine]] counselled a total of 156,729 children, 26,134 of whom spoke about bullying as a main concern and 300 of whom spoke specifically about sexual bullying.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nspcc.org.uk/Inform/policyandpublicaffairs/policysummaries/sexual_bullying_in_education_settings_wdf68771.pdf |title=NSPCC policy summary |publisher=NSPCC |accessdate=22 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613025631/http://www.nspcc.org.uk/Inform/policyandpublicaffairs/policysummaries/sexual_bullying_in_education_settings_wdf68771.pdf | archive-date=13 June 2010}}</ref>
The U.K. charity [[Beatbullying]] has claimed that as [[gang culture]] enters, children are being bullied into providing sexual favours in exchange for protection.<ref name="BBC02">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/6500005.stm |title=Girls bullied for 'sex favours' |publisher=BBC |date=27 March 2007 |accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref> However, other anti-bullying groups and teachers' unions, including the [[National Union of Teachers]], challenged the charity to provide evidence of this.<ref name="BBC02" />
Sexting cases are also on the rise and have become a major source of bullying. The circulation of explicit photos of those involved either around school or the internet put the originators in a position to be scorned and bullied.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eyepat.org/sexting |title=Sexting |publisher=EyePAT |date= |accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref> There have been reports of some cases in which the bullying has been so extensive that the victim has taken their life.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hastings |first=Katy |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1161112/Teenager-commits-suicide-sexting-nude-photo-boyfriend-life-misery.html |title=Teenager commits suicide after 'sexting' a nude photo to her boyfriend made her life a misery |work=Daily Mail |date=10 March 2009 |accessdate=14 September 2015}}</ref>
=== Higher education bullying === According to HealthDay News, 15 percent of college students claim to have been victims of bullying while at college.<ref>{{cite web |last1=King |first1=Michelle |title=The Truth About Bullying in College |url=http://www.hercampus.com/health/mental-health/truth-about-bullying-college |website=HerCampus.com |accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref> In the article, "Bullying not a thing of the past for college students," Kaitlyn Krasselt writes, "Bullying comes in all forms but is usually thought of as a K-12 issue that ceases to exist once students head off to college."<ref name=usatoday>{{cite web |last1=Krasselt |first1=Kaitlyn |title=Bullying not a thing of the past for college students |url=http://college.usatoday.com/2014/10/21/bullying-not-a-thing-of-the-past-for-college-students/ |website=usatoday.com |date=21 October 2014}}</ref> The misconception that bullying does not occur in higher education began to receive attention after the death of college student [[Suicide of Tyler Clementi|Tyler Clementi]]. According to an experiment conducted by Dr. Gary R. Walz, "21.47% of participants reported rarely being victims of cyberbullying; 93.29% reported rarely cyberbullying others. Overall, there was a low prevalence rate for cyberbullying."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Walz |first=Garry |date=2016 |title=Cyberbullying on Social Media Among College Students |url=https://www.counseling.org/docs/default-source/vistas/article_03b0bf24f16116603abcacff0000bee5e7.pdf?sfvrsn=4 |journal=Vistas Online |volume= |pages=8 |via=}}</ref>
== Power imbalance == Bullying is usually associated with an imbalance of [[Power (social and political)|power]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Meyer |first=Doug |date= |title=The Gentle Neoliberalism of Modern Anti-bullying Texts: Surveillance, Intervention, and Bystanders in Contemporary Bullying Discourse |url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s13178-016-0238-9 |journal=Sexuality Research & Social Policy |volume=13 |issue=4 |page=356 |via= |doi=10.1007/s13178-016-0238-9 |year=2016}}</ref> A bully has a perceived authority over another due to factors such as size, gender, or age.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Sylvester, Ruth |title=Teacher as Bully: Knowingly or Unintentionally Harming Students |journal=Morality in Education |year=2011 |pages=42–45 |volume=77 |issue=2 |url=http://www.deltakappagamma.org/NH/dkgbulletinwinter2011.PDF#page=42}}</ref> Boys tend to bully peers based on the peer's physical weakness, short temper, friend group, and clothing. Bullying among girls, on the other hand, results from factors such as facial appearance, [[emotional]] factors, being [[overweight]], and academic status.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |pmid=18447077 |url=http://njbullying.org/documents/beaty-adolesc-research3-08.pdf |year=2008 |last1=Beaty |first1=LA |last2=Alexeyev |first2=EB |title=The problem of school bullies: What the research tells us |volume=43 |issue=169 |pages=1–11 |journal=Adolescence}}</ref> Both sexes tend to target people with [[speech impediment]]s of some sort (such as stutter).
Bullies often come from families that use physical forms of discipline.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |doi=10.1023/A:1026695430820 |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=83–106 |last1=Nelson |first1=E. D. |last2=Lambert |first2=R. D. |title=Sticks, Stones and Semantics: The Ivory Tower Bully's Vocabulary of Motives |journal=Qualitative Sociology |year=2001}} {{closed access}}</ref>
== Locations == Bullying locations vary by context. Most bullying in elementary school happens in the playground. In middle school and high school, it occurs most in the hallways, which have little supervision. According to the [[US Department of Education|U.S Department of Education]]'s [[National Center for Education Statistics]], more than 47% of kids reported getting bullied in hallways and stairway.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.jrn.msu.edu/bullying/2012/02/16/bullying-locations/ |title=Hallways, stairwells are bullying hot spots |work=The New Bullying | access-date = 26 February 2016}}</ref> Bus stops and bus rides to and from school tend to be hostile environments as well; children tend to view the driver as someone with no disciplinary authority.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.keepyourchildsafe.org/bullying/where-bullying-occurs.html |title=The places where bullying occurs; where bullying takes place |website=Child Safety and Abuse Prevention Programs| access-date = 26 February 2016}}</ref>
Bullying may also follows people into adult life and university. Bullying can take over the lives of both lecturers and students, and can lead to supervisors putting pressure on students.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Norman, O'Higgins |first=Jmes |year=2016 |title=2. Bullying among University Students |url=https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P3-4055733771/2-bullying-among-university-students |journal=International Journal of Emotional Education |volume=8 |pages= |via=}}</ref> Bullying can happen in any place at any time.
== Warning signs == Victims of bullying typically are physically smaller, more sensitive, unhappy, cautious, anxious, quiet, and withdrawn. They are often described as [[passivity (behavior)|passive]] or submissive. Possessing these qualities make these individuals vulnerable, as they are seen as being less likely to retaliate.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
Signs that a child is being bullied include:<ref name="United States 2013" /><ref name="Victimology">{{cite book |publisher=SAGE Publications, Inc. |isbn=978-1-4129-6047-2 |last1=Fisher |first1=Bonnie |last2=Lab |first2=Steven |last3=Miller |first3=Holly Ventura |last4=Miller |first4=J. Mitchell |title=Encyclopedia of Victimology and Crime Prevention |chapter=School-Based Bullying Prevention |location=California |date=2010 |chapterurl=http://sk.sagepub.com/reference/victimologyandcrime/n275.xml |doi=10.4135/9781412979993.n274 |pages=818–820 }}</ref> * Unexplainable injuries * Showing [[anxiety]] and [[post-traumatic stress]] * Lost or destroyed clothing * Changes in eating habits * Declining grades * Continual school absences * Self-injury * Suicidal tendencies * Becoming overly apologetic
Signs that a child is bullying others include:<ref name="United States 2013" /><ref name="Victimology" /> * Getting into physical or verbal fights * Getting sent to the principal's office frequently * Having friends who bully others * Becoming increasingly aggressive in normal activities
Signs that a child has witnessed bullying include:<ref name="United States 2013" /><ref name="Victimology" /> * Poor school behavior * Emotional disturbance * Depression * Post-traumatic stress * Drug and alcohol abuse * Suicidal tendencies
== Roles == [[File:Wikibully.jpg|thumb|Cartoon representation of a bully and a victim used to depict [[Western Europe]]an powers and the United States "bullying" [[Serbia]] in the aftermath of the [[2008 Kosovo declaration of independence]] during the [[2008 Serbian protests]]]] McNamee and Mercurio state that there is a "bullying triangle", consisting of the person doing the bullying, the person getting bullied, and the bystander.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/00094056.2008.10523045 |volume=84 |issue=6 |pages=370–378 |last1=McNamee |first1=Abigail |last2=Mercurio |first2=Mia |title=School-Wide Intervention in the Childhood Bullying Triangle |journal=Childhood Education |date=1 August 2008}} {{closed access}}</ref>
The [[US Department of Health and Human Services]] divides the people involved in bullying into several roles:<ref name="United States 2013">{{cite web |last=US Department of Health and Human Services |title=The Roles Kids Play |work=What is Bullying |accessdate=25 September 2013 |date=16 October 2012 |url=http://www.stopbullying.gov/what-is-bullying/roles-kids-play/index.html}}</ref> * '''Bully''': student with social and/or physical power who repeatedly picks on another student or group of students with the intent to inflict harm or discomfort * '''Victim''': the target of the bullying * '''Bystander''': student who observes bullying; they may ignore it, encourage it, or defend the victim * '''Student who assists''': does not start the bullying, but helps and is encouraged by surrounding peers to do so. They may feel that their social status will be damaged if they are not involved. * '''Student who reinforces''': play a minor role in bullying, such as laughing at the bully's insults * '''Outsider''': not involved in the bullying but witnesses it * '''Defendant''': defends the victim or consoles them afterwards
In her book, ''[[The Bully, the Bullied, and the Bystander]]'', Barbara Coloroso divides bullies into several types:<ref>{{cite book |publisher=Collins Living [HarperResource] |isbn=978-0-06-174460-0 |last=Coloroso |first=Barbara |title=The Bully, the Bullied, and the Bystander: From Preschool To High School – How Parents and Teachers Can Help Break the Cycle of Violence |location=New York |year=2004 |pages=11–41}}</ref> *The '''confident bully''' has a very high opinion of themselves and feels a sense of superiority over other students. *The '''social bully''' uses rumors, gossip, and verbal taunts to insult others. Social bullies are typically female and possess low self-esteem, and therefore try to bring others down. *The '''fully armored bully''' shows very little emotion and often bullies when no one will see or stop them. *The '''hyperactive bully''' typically has problems with academics and social skills. This student will often bully someone, then place the blame on someone else. *A '''bullied bully''' is usually someone who has been bullied in the past or is bullied by an older sibling. * A '''"bunch of bullies"''' (more often referred to as a "'''gang of bullies"''') is a group of friends who gang up on others for fun or due to their desire for power.
== Complex cultural dynamics == Parsons identifies school [[bullying culture]]s as typically having a web of [[Group dynamics|dynamics]] which are much more complex than just considering bullying amongst students. These dynamics include:<ref name="Parsons">{{cite book |first=Les |last=Parsons |title=Bullied Teacher – Bullied Student: How to Recognize the Bullying Culture in Your School And What to Do About It |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k_wXp4pUJeQC |year=2005 |publisher=Pembroke Publishers Limited |isbn=978-1-55138-190-9}}</ref> * '''Some students bully''' other students; some of these student bullies are themselves bullied by other student bullies; some of these student bullies bully teachers. * '''Some teachers bully''' students; some teacher bullies bully other teachers; some teacher bullies bully parents. * '''Some office staff bully''' teachers, students and parents. * '''Some [[Head teacher|principals]] bully''' teachers, office staff, students and parents. * '''Some parents bully''' teachers, office staff, principals, and even their own children.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Dake |first=J. A. |author2=Price, J. H. |author3=Telljohann, S. K. |title=The nature and extent of bullying in school |pmid=12793102 |url=http://www2.gsu.edu/~wwwche/The%20Nature%20and%20Extent%20of%20Bullying%20at%20School.pdf |journal=The Journal of School Health |year=2003 |volume=73 |issue=5 |doi=10.1111/j.1746-1561.2003.tb03599.x |pages=173–80}}</ref>
== Common misconceptions == Researchers have identified many misconceptions regarding bullying:<ref name="Olweus 2003 12">{{cite journal |last=Olweus |first=Dan |title=A Profile of Bullying at School |journal=Educational Leadership |date=March 2003 |volume=60 |issue=6 |page=12 |url=http://lhsela.weebly.com/uploads/7/9/0/8/7908073/_olweus_profile_of_bullying.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Scarpaci |first=Richard |title=Bullying: Effective Strategies for Its Prevention |journal=Kappa Delta Pi Record |year=2006 |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=170–174 |doi=10.1080/00228958.2006.10518023 |url=http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ738087.pdf}}</ref>
* Bullying is a consequence of [[Class size|large class or school size]]. * Bullying is a consequence of competition for grades and failure in school. * Bullying is a consequence of poor self-esteem and insecurity. * Bullying is just teasing. * Some people deserve to be bullied. * Only boys are bullies. * Bullying is a normal part of growing up. * Bullies will go away if ignored. * The best way to deal with a bully is by fighting or trying to get even. * People who are bullied will only hurt for a while before recovering. * Bullying is thought of as a K-12 issue that ceases to exist once students enter college.<ref name=usatoday/>
== Prevention == Studies have shown that bullying programs set up in schools with the help and engagements of staff and faculty have been shown to reduce peer victimization and bullying.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=O'Brennan |first1=L. M. |last2=Waasdorp |first2=T. E. |last3=Bradshaw |first3=C. P. |year=2014 |title=Strengthening bullying prevention through school staff connectedness |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Tracy_Waasdorp/publication/270940545_Strengthening_Bullying_Prevention_Through_School_Staff_Connectedness/links/55ce6fee08aee19936fc5be3.pdf |journal=Journal of Educational Psychology |volume=106 |issue=3 |pages=870–880 |doi=10.1037/a0035957}}</ref> Incidences of bullying are noticeably reduced when the students themselves disapprove of bullying.<ref>{{cite book |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-533587-3| editor1-last = Vernberg| editor1-first = Eric M | editor2-last = Biggs| editor2-first = Bridget K |last1=Guerra |first1=Nancy G |last2=Williams |first2=Kirk R |title=Preventing and treating bullying and victimization |chapter=Implementing bullying prevention in diverse settings : geographic, economic, and cultural influences |location=New York |date=2010 |oclc=426066162}}</ref>
Measures such as increasing awareness,{{Contradict-inline|date=September 2016}} instituting [[Zero tolerance (schools)|zero tolerance]] for fighting, or placing troubled students in the same group or classroom are actually ineffective in reducing bullying; methods that ''are'' effective include increasing empathy for victims; adopting a program that includes teachers, students, and parents; and having students lead anti-bullying efforts.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |title=Invitation to the Life Span |last=Berger |first=Kathleen Stassen |publisher=Worth Publishers |year=2014 |isbn=1464172056 |location=New York |pages=}}</ref>{{pages needed|date=September 2016}} Success is most associated with beginning interventions at an early age, constantly evaluating programs for effectiveness, and having some students simply take online classes to avoid bullies at school.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.detweedeverdieping.nu/images/pdf/Update%20on%20bullying%20at%20school.pdf |title=Update on bullying at school: Science forgotten? |last=Berger |first=Kathleen Stassen |date=2007 |journal=Developmental Review |doi=10.1016/j.dr.2006.08.002 |pmid= |volume=27 |pages=90–126}}</ref>
=== Legislation and court rulings === {{Main|Anti-bullying legislation}}{{Expand section|date=September 2016}}[[File:School bullying laws in the United States.svg|right|thumb|Some U.S. states have implemented laws to address school bullying. {{legend|#800080|Law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#0066ff|Law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation only}} {{legend|#14a800|Law that prohibits bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#ba75ff|School regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#00ffff|School regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation only}} {{legend|#d40000|Law that forbids school-based instruction of LGBT issues in a positive manner}} {{legend|#7f7f7f|Law that prohibits bullying in school but lists no categories of protection}} {{legend|#cccccc|No statewide law that specifically prohibits bullying in schools}}]]
==== United Kingdom ==== Section 89 of the [[Education and Inspections Act 2006]] provides for an anti-bullying policy for all state schools to be made available to parents.
==== United States ==== The victims of some school shootings have sued both the shooters' families and the schools.<ref>{{cite web |last=Brownstein |first=Andrew |title=The bully pulpit: post-Columbine harassment victims take schools to court |work=Trial |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+bully+pulpit:+post-Columbine+harassment+victims+take+schools+to...-a097175612 |date=December 2002}}</ref> At one point only 23 states had Anti-Bullying laws. In 2015 Montana became the last state to have an anti-bullying law and at that point all 50 states had an anti-bullying law. These laws are not going to abolish bullying but it does bring attention to the behavior and it lets the aggressors know it will not be tolerated.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/deborah-temkin/all-50-states-now-have-a_b_7153114.html |title=All 50 States Now have a Bullying Law. Now What? |last=Temkin |first=Deborah |date=27 April 2015 |work=Huffington Post}}</ref>
==== Canada ==== In 2016, a legal precedent was set by a mother and her son, after the son was bullied at his public school. The mother and son won a court case against the [[Ottawa-Carleton District School Board]], making this the first case in North America where a [[school board]] has been found negligent in a bullying case for failing to meet the standard of care (the "[[duty of care]]" that the school board owes to its students). A similar bullying case was won in Australia in 2013 (''Oyston v. St. Patricks College'').<ref>{{cite web |last=Murray |first=Melissa |title=Family wins precedent-setting case against public school board |work=Ottawa Community News |date=19 June 2016 |url=http://www.ottawacommunitynews.com/news-story/6773614-family-wins-precedent-setting-case-against-public-school-board/}}</ref>
=== Taiwan === The [[Ministry of Education (Taiwan)|Ministry of Education]] launched a serial of project. In 2006, they started the 'anti-bully plan'. In 2008, they launched the 'prevent bully video from public project', and also building multiple informants route, monitoring the school, in hope that it could improve the education quality.<ref>The education analysis and anti policy. 陳利銘、鄭英耀、黃正鵠(2010)。反霸凌政策之分析與改進建議。教育政策論壇，13(3)，1–25。</ref>
=== School shootings === {{main|School shootings}} School bullying is associated with school shootings; the vast majority of students (87%) believe that shootings occur in direct retaliation to bullying.<ref name="NoBullying">{{cite web |title=School Bullying Statistics |url=http://nobullying.com/school-bullying-statistics/ |accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> School shooters who left behind evidence that they were bullied include [[Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold]] (perpetrators of the [[Columbine High School massacre]]), Nathan Ferris, Edmar Aparecido Freitas, Brian Head, [[Seung-Hui Cho]], [[Wellington Menezes Oliveira]], [[Kimveer Gill]], [[Karl Pierson]], and [[Jeff Weise]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Bully Facts & Statistics |work=Make Beats Not Beat Downs | archive-date=25 December 2013 |url=http://makebeatsnotbeatdowns.org/facts_new.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131225040814/http://makebeatsnotbeatdowns.org/facts_new.html}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=September 2016}}
== Events and organizations == Events and organizations which address bullying in schools include: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Act Against Bullying]] * [[BeatBullying]] * [[Bully-Free ABA!]] * [[The Bully Police Squad]] * [[Bullying UK]] * [[Bystander Revolution]] * [[Ditch the Label]] * [[GRIN Campaign]] * [[Jer's Vision]] * [[Kidpower (organization)|Kidpower]] * [[Kidscape]] }}
== See also == {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Amanda Todd]] * [[Sack tapping]] * [[School violence]] * [[Sexual harassment in education]] * [[School-related gender-based violence (SRGBV)]] }}
== Sources == {{Free-content attribution | title = School Violence and Bullying: Global Status Report | author = UNESCO | publisher = UNESCO | page numbers = 17, 29–31 | source = UNESCO | documentURL = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0024/002469/246970e.pdf | license statement URL = http://www.unesco.org/ulis/cgi-bin/ulis.pl?catno=246970&set=0058E287A6_3_124&gp=1&lin=1&ll=1 | license = CC-BY-SA IGO 3.0 }}

== Further reading == * Harger, Brent (2016). [http://cupola.gettysburg.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1029&context=socfac "You Say Bully, I Say Bullied: School Culture and Definitions of Bullying in Two Elementary Schools."] Education and Youth Today. Ed. Yasemin Besen-Cassino and Loretta E. Bass (Sociological Studies of Children and Youth, Volume 20) Emerald Group Publishing Limited, 2016. 91 – 121. * {{cite book |author1=National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine |authorlink1=National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine|editor1-last=Rivara|editor1-first=Frederick|editor2-last=Suzanne|editor2-first=Le Menestrel |title=Preventing Bullying Through Science, Policy, and Practice |date=2016 |publisher=[[National Academies Press]] |isbn=978-0-309-44067-7 |doi=10.17226/23482 |url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog/23482/preventing-bullying-through-science-policy-and-practice}} {{Open access}} * Stuart W. [[Image:Sun symbol.svg|right|thumb|The central dot is the Ego whereas the Self is both the whole and the centered dot]] The '''Self in Jungian psychology''' is one of the [[Jungian archetypes]], signifying the unification of consciousness and unconsciousness in a person, and representing the psyche as a whole.<ref>Josepf L. Henderson, "Ancient Myths and Modern Man" in C. G. Jung ed., ''Man and his Symbols'' (London 1978) p. 120</ref> The Self, according to [[Carl Jung]], is realized as the product of [[individuation]], which in his view is the process of integrating one's personality. For Jung, the Self is symbolized by the [[circled dot|circle]] (especially when divided in four quadrants), the [[square (geometry)|square]], or the [[mandala]].
==Twin centers==
What distinguishes Jungian psychology is the idea that there are two centers of the personality. The [[Id, ego and super-ego#Ego|ego]] is the center of consciousness, whereas the Self is the center of the total personality, which includes consciousness, the unconscious, and the ego. The Self is both the whole and the center. While the ego is a self-contained little center of the circle contained within the whole, the Self can be understood as the greater circle.<ref>{{cite book | last = Zweig | first = Connie | title = Meeting the Shadow | publisher = J.P. Tarcher | location = Los Angeles | year = 1991 | isbn = 0-87477-618-X }} p. 24.</ref>
==Emergence from the Self==
Jung considered that from birth every individual has an original sense of wholeness - of the Self - but that with development a separate ego-consciousness crystallizes out of the original feeling of unity.<ref>Henderson, "Myths" p. 120</ref> This process of ego-differentiation provides the task of the first half of one's life-course, though Jungians also saw psychic health as depending on a periodic return to the sense of Self, something facilitated by the use of myths, initiation ceremonies, and [[rites of passage]]. <ref>Henderson, "Myths" p. 120</ref>
==Return to the Self: individuation==
Once ego-differentiation had been successfully achieved and the individual is securely anchored in the external world, Jung considered that a new task then arose for the second half of life - a return to, and conscious rediscovery of, the Self: individuation. [[Marie-Louise von Franz]] states that "The actual processes of individuation - the conscious coming-to-term with one's own inner center (psychic nucleus) or Self - generally begins with a wounding of the personality".<ref>M-L von Franz, "The Process of Individuation" in Jung ed., ''Symbols'' p. 169</ref> The ego reaches an impasse of one sort or another; and has to turn for help to what she termed "a sort of hidden regulating or directing tendency...[an] organizing center" in the personality: "Jung called this center the 'Self' and described it as the totality of the whole psyche, in order to distinguish it from the 'ego', which constitutes only a small part of the psyche".<ref>von Franz, "Process" p. 161-2</ref>
Under the Self's guidance, a succession of archetypal images emerges,<ref>Jolandi Jacobi, ''The Psychology of C. G. Jung'' (London 1968) p. 40</ref> gradually bringing their fragmentary aspects of the Self increasingly closer to its totality. The first to appear, and the closest to the ego, would be the [[Shadow (psychology)|shadow]] or personal unconscious - something which is at the same time the first representative of the total personality,<ref>Barbara Hannah, ''Striving towards Wholeness'' (Boston 1988) p. 25</ref> and which may indeed be at times conflated with the Self.<ref>von Franz "Process" p. 182-3</ref> Next to appear would be the [[Anima and Animus]], the soul-image, which again, by a kind of psychological short-cut, may be taken as identical to the whole Self.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''[[Alchemical Studies]]'' (London 1978) p. 268</ref> Ideally however, the animus or anima comes to play a mediatory role between the ego and the Self.<ref>von Franz "Process" p. 193 and p. 195</ref> The third main archetype to emerge is the [[Mana]] figure of the wise old man/woman<ref>J. Jacobi, ''The Psychology of C. G. Jung'' (London 1946) p. 115</ref> - a representative of the collective unconscious still closer to the Self.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious'' (London 1996) p. 183 and p. 187</ref>
Thereafter comes the archetype of the Self itself - the last point on the route to self-realization of individuation.<ref>Jacobi (1946) p. 118</ref> In Jung's words, "the Self...embraces ego-consciousness, shadow, anima, and collective unconscious in indeterminable extension. As a totality, the self is a ''coincidentia oppositorum''; it is therefore bright and dark and yet neither".<ref>C. G. Jung, ''Mysterium Coniunctionis'' (London 1963) p. 108n</ref> Alternatively, he stated that "the Self is the total, timeless man...who stands for the mutual integration of conscious and unconscious".<ref>C. G .Jung, "Psychology of the Transference", ''Collected Works'' Vol. 16 (London 1954) p. 311</ref> Jung recognized many dream images as representing the self, including a stone, the [[world tree]], an elephant, and the Christ.<ref>On this last, see "Christ, a Symbol of the Self" in ''Collected Works'' Vol. 9ii, p. 36ff. He explicitly says, "''Christ exemplifies the archetype of the self.''" [italics his]</ref>
==Perils of the Self==
Von Franz considered that "the dark side of the Self is the most dangerous thing of all, precisely because the Self is the greatest power in the psyche. It can cause people to 'spin' [[megalomania|megalomanic]] or other delusionary fantasies that catch them up", so that the victim "thinks with mounting excitement that he has grasped the great cosmic riddles; he therefore loses all touch with human reality. <ref>von Franz, ''Process'', p.234.</ref>
In everyday life, the Self may be projected onto such powerful figures as the state, God, the universe or fate.<ref>Anthony Stevens, ''On Jung'' (London 1990) p. 41</ref> When such projections are withdrawn, there can be a destructive inflation of the personality - one potential counterbalance to this being however the social or collective aspects of the Self.<ref>von Franz, ''Process'', p. 238.</ref>
==Criticism of the Jungian concept of Self==
[[Fritz Perls]] may have had the Jungians in mind when he objected that 'many psychologists like to write the self with a capital S, as if the self would be something precious, something extraordinarily valuable. They go at the discovery of the self like a treasure-digging. The self means nothing but this thing as it is defined by ''otherness'''.<ref>Fritz Perls, ''Gestalt Therapy Verbatim'' (Bantam) p. 8</ref>
Young-Eisendrath and Hall write that 'in Jung's work, self can refer to the notion of inherent subjective individuality, the idea of an abstract center or central ordering principle, and the account of a process developing over time'.<ref>Polly Young-Eisendrath/James Albert Hall, ''Jung's Self-Psychology'' (1991) p. 5</ref>
